{{Infobox person | name = Aja | image = | caption = | birth_name = Jay Rivera | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|01|04}}{{cite tweet |user=ajaqueen |author=Aja |number=948954378454515712 |date=January 4, 2018 |title=God its my birthday yall. 24 years old never seemed more anti climatic lol. But i guess ill combine my farewell 2017 post with my birthday post.
This past year has definitely been one for the books. |archive-date=February 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180224112015/https:/twitter.com/ajaqueen/status/948954378454515712 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |dead-url=no}} | death_date = | residence = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | nationality = American | occupation = {{Flatlist| * [[Drag queen]] * rapper }} | known_for = {{flatlist| * ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'' ([[RuPaul's Drag Race (season 9)|season 9]]) * ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race: All Stars]]'' ([[RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars (season 3)|season 3]]) }} | website = {{URL|ajakween.com}} }} '''Aja''' is the stage name of '''Jay Rivera''' (born January 4, 1994),{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com.au/rupauls-drag-race-season-9-episode-1-lady-gaga-queens-spoilers-1546235|title='RuPaul's Drag Race' season 9 episode 1: Lady Gaga, the Queens and spoilers|first=Edana|last=Patricio|date=March 9, 2017|work=[[International Business Times]] |publisher=[[Newsweek Media Group]] |accessdate=February 21, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027125658/http://www.ibtimes.com.au/rupauls-drag-race-season-9-episode-1-lady-gaga-queens-spoilers-1546235 |archive-date=October 27, 2017 |dead-url=no}} an American [[drag queen|drag performer]], reality television personality, rapper, and queer artist best known for competing on [[RuPaul's Drag Race (season 9)|season 9]] of ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'' and [[RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars (season 3)|season 3]] of ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race: All Stars]]''. Aja released the EP ''[[In My Feelings (EP)|In My Feelings]]'' in 2018, and they currently host a web series called ''Ayo Sis'' on [[World of Wonder (company)|WOW]] Presents Plus. ==Career== [[File:Rupaul Dragcon 2018-227 (40268259480).jpg|thumb|left|Aja (left) and [[Alyssa Edwards]] (right) at RuPaul's DragCon LA 2018]] Rivera began doing drag in [[Manhattan]] at age 16, participating in contests at Posh Bar, the [[Stonewall Inn]], Metropolitan Bar and Sugarland.{{cite news|url=https://www.amny.com/entertainment/drag-race-aja-1.16722323 |title=Bushwick's 'Drag Race' contestant Aja explains the therapeutic power of drag |last=Giannotta |first=Meghan |date=February 13, 2018 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |newspaper=[[AM New York]] |publisher=Rich Tomko |archive-date=February 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180224112445/https://www.amny.com/entertainment/drag-race-aja-1.16722323 |dead-url=no}} Aja was announced to be competing on the [[RuPaul's Drag Race (season 9)|ninth season]] of ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'' alongside 13 other contestants on February 2, 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.logotv.com/shows/rupauls-drag-race/cast|title=RuPaul's Drag Race Cast {{!}} logotv.com|website=[[Logo TV]]|access-date=February 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114103309/http://www.logotv.com/shows/rupauls-drag-race/cast |archive-date=November 14, 2017}} Aja placed ninth overall, later returning for the [[RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars (season 3)|third season]] of ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race: All Stars]]'' on October 20, 2017.{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/10/20/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-season-3-cast-aja/ |title='RuPaul's Drag Race' reveals first 'All Stars 3' cast member |last=Nolfi |first=Joey |date=October 20, 2017 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]] |archive-date=February 21, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221005747/http://ew.com/tv/2017/10/20/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-season-3-cast-aja/ |dead-url=no}} Aja was eliminated during the fifth episode, but returned in the following episode with the other eliminated queens for a chance to win re-entry into the competition.{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/02/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-recap-season-3-episode-5.html |title=''RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars'' Recap: Survival Art |date=February 22, 2018 |last1=Yang |first1=Bowen |last2=Rogers |first2=Matt |website=[[New York (magazine)#Digital expansion and blogs|Vulture]] |publisher=New York Media, LLC |access-date=February 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180223175726/http://www.vulture.com/2018/02/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-recap-season-3-episode-5.html |archive-date=February 23, 2018 |dead-url=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/03/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-recap-season-3-episode-6.html |title=''RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars'' Recap: Messy Girls |date=March 1, 2018 |last1=Yang |first1=Bowen |last2=Rogers |first2=Matt |website=Vulture |publisher=New York Media, LLC |access-date=March 7, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180302191115/http://www.vulture.com/2018/03/rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-recap-season-3-episode-6.html |archive-date=March 2, 2018 |dead-url=no}} [[Morgan McMichaels]] rejoined the competition, which placed Aja seventh overall. In March 2018, Aja hosted a [[Live streaming|live streamed]] ''Drag Race'' trivia contest with the cast of [[RuPaul's Drag Race (season 10)|season 10]].{{cite AV media |author=[[VH1]] |date=March 22, 2018 |title=‚ú® Aja Tests the Cast of RuPaul's Drag Race Season 10 w/ the #DragRace Herstory Quiz {{!}} VH1 |medium=[[YouTube]] video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P4e-GN1e21M |access-date=May 3, 2018}} The [[drag house]] Haus of Aja, based in [[Bedford‚ÄìStuyvesant, Brooklyn]], includes members Aja, Kandy Muse, Momo Shade, Dahlia Sin, and Janelle No5.{{cite web |url= https://www.grizzlykiki.com/podcast/podcast/the-haus-of-aja|title=The Haus of Aja |date=November 18, 2016 |website=Grizzly Kiki |access-date=February 22, 2018}}{{cite tweet |author=Aja |user=ajaqueen |number=985979107333853185 |date=April 16, 2018 |title=The #Hausofaja would like to present to you our newest member @janelle.no.5 !!! We love this hoe and can't wait to see what this woman adds to our collective ‚ú®üíï @dahlia_sin @thekandymuse @momoshade photo by @orograph |archive-date=April 17, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417173933/https:/twitter.com/ajaqueen/status/985979107333853185 |access-date=April 17, 2018 |dead-url=no}} The group perform at Hardware Bar.{{cite web |url=https://brokelyn.com/brooklyn-drag-crews/ |title=5 Brooklyn drag supergroups ripe for your adoration |last=Shorey |first=Eric |date=June 13, 2017 |website=Brokelyn |access-date=February 22, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222044227/https://brokelyn.com/brooklyn-drag-crews/ |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |dead-url=no}} Aja appeared in a commercial for [[H&M]]'s Pride OUT Loud campaign in May 2018.{{Cite news |url=https://nylon.com/articles/hm-pride-2018-aja-interview |title=Aja Is The Face Of H&M‚Äôs New Pride OUT Loud Campaign |date=May 24, 2018 |magazine=[[Nylon (magazine)|Nylon]] |access-date=June 5, 2018 |last=Igneri |first=Jenna |archive-date=May 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180524232852/https://nylon.com/articles/hm-pride-2018-aja-interview |dead-url=no}} Since June 2018, Aja has hosted a talk show called ''Ayo Sis'' on [[World of Wonder (company)|WOW]] Presents Plus.{{cite news |url=http://ew.com/tv/2018/06/25/miss-vanjie-tv-show-follow-me/ |last=Nolfi |first=Joey |title=Vaaanjie! Find out which RuPaul's Drag Race alums are getting their own TV shows |date=June 25, 2018 |magazine=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Meredith Corporation |access-date=July 3, 2018 |archive-date=June 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180625222444/http://ew.com/tv/2018/06/25/miss-vanjie-tv-show-follow-me/ |dead-url=no}} In July 2018, Rivera announced that they no longer wish to be known as a drag queen, but rather as a queer artist, stating to ''them. Magazine'': {{Quote|[B]eing a queer artist is more generalized, and being a drag queen is way more specific. I know I kind of let go of the idea of being a drag queen because, for most people, the stereotypical drag queen lip syncs and performs. I've been working on my burlesque and my live music, and I don't really have the drive to dance and flip flop and be doing dips and, 'Is she gonna jump from there?' It's just not something I want to do. It's something that is part of me, but it's not something that I'm carrying into the future, so I‚Äôm kind of leaving the term behind.{{cite news |url=https://www.them.us/story/aja-queer-performance |title=Why 'Drag Race' Alum Aja Is No Longer Using the Term 'Drag Queen' |last=Street |first=Mikelle |date=July 3, 2018 |access-date=July 4, 2018 |magazine=them. |publisher=[[Cond√© Nast]] |archive-date=July 4, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180704002930/https://www.them.us/story/aja-queer-performance |dead-url=yes}}}} == Music == Aja released the single "Level Ya Pussy Up" with producers WNNR and DJ Accident Report in February 2017.{{Cite web|title=Level Ya Pussy Up (feat. WNNR & DJ Accident Report) - Single |date=February 2, 2017|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/level-ya-pussy-up-feat-wnnr-dj-accident-report-single/1335402765|accessdate=February 21, 2018|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]}} Aja's single with fellow season 9 queens [[Sasha Velour]], [[Peppermint (drag queen)|Peppermint]] and [[Alexis Michelle]], titled "C.L.A.T.", was released on April 21, 2017.{{Cite journal |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7767972/rupauls-drag-race-new-york-city-queens-clat |title='RuPaul's Drag Race' Season 9 Queens From NYC Team Up for 'C.L.A.T.' Video: Exclusive |date=April 21, 2017 |first=Joe |last=Lynch |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |accessdate=February 21, 2018|issn=0006-2510 |publisher=Lynne Segall |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820184316/http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7767972/rupauls-drag-race-new-york-city-queens-clat |archive-date=August 20, 2017 |dead-url=no}}{{Cite journal|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/7966091/rupauls-drag-race-best-songs-queens|title=17 Best Songs From 'RuPaul's Drag Race' Queens|date=September 19, 2017|first=Joe|last=Lynch|work=Billboard|accessdate=February 21, 2018 |publisher=Lynne Segall |archive-date=November 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171102021524/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/7966091/rupauls-drag-race-best-songs-queens |dead-url=no}} The track was produced by DJ Mitch Ferrino, who was featured on "Purse First" by [[Bob the Drag Queen]].{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/c-l-a-t-feat-dj-mitch-ferrino/1224249908?i=1224251423|title=C.L.A.T. (feat. DJ Mitch Ferrino) - Single|date=April 21, 2017|publisher=iTunes Store|accessdate=February 21, 2018}} Producer [[Adam Joseph]] remixed Aja's rant at competing season 9 queen [[Valentina (drag queen)|Valentina]] in a track called "Linda Evangelista."{{cite web |url=http://www.newnownext.com/aja-valentina-untucked-dance-song/04/2017/ |title=Aja's 'Untucked' Valentina Read Has Been Turned Into A Killer Club Track |last=Rudolph |first=Christopher |date=April 17, 2017 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |website=[[Logo TV#Online|NewNowNext]] |publisher=Logo TV |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222044452/http://www.newnownext.com/aja-valentina-untucked-dance-song/04/2017/ |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |dead-url=no}}{{cite web |url=https://mic.com/articles/174735/model-linda-evangelista-shows-love-to-rpdr-by-posting-iconic-aja-valentina-meme-on-ig#.8MIS29L32 |title=Model Linda Evangelista shows love to 'RPDR' by posting iconic Aja/Valentina meme on IG |last= Katz|first= Evan|date=April 20, 2017 |website=[[Mic (media company)|Mic]] |publisher=Mic Network Inc. |access-date=February 24, 2018}}{{Cite web|title=Linda Evangelista - Single|date=May 3, 2017|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/linda-evangelista-feat-aja/1234035664?i=1234035665|accessdate=February 21, 2018|publisher=iTunes Store}} In September 2017, Aja appeared in the music video for Velo's song "Big D*ck Daddy" alongside [[Phi Phi O'Hara]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newnownext.com/velo-big-dick-daddy-music-video-aja-phi-phi-o-hara/09/2017/ |title=Aja And Phi Phi O'Hara Want a "Big D*ck Daddy" in New Velo Music Video |website=NewNowNext |publisher=Logo TV |last=Rudolph |first=Christopher |date=September 4, 2017 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222043848/http://www.newnownext.com/velo-big-dick-daddy-music-video-aja-phi-phi-o-hara/09/2017/ |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |dead-url=no}} On March 1, 2018, Aja released a solo music video, "Finish Her!", which was produced in collaboration with WNNR and Accident Report. It features some of Aja's runway looks from ''All Stars 3''. Their debut EP, ''[[In My Feelings (EP)|In My Feelings]]'', was released on May 11, 2018.{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/8455498/aja-music-rupauls-drag-race-ep-interview |last=Lynch |first=Joe |date=May 11, 2018 |title= 'Drag Race' All Star Aja on Her Debut EP, 'Classism' In the New York Drag Scene & Rejecting the Gender Binary |magazine=Billboard |publisher=Lynne Segall|access-date=May 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512001258/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/8455498/aja-music-rupauls-drag-race-ep-interview |archive-date=May 12, 2018 |dead-url=no}} Videos for two other songs from ''In My Feelings'', "Brujer√≠a" and "I Don't Wanna Brag," were released on May 7, 2018, and July 13, 2018, respectively. ==Personal life== Rivera is of [[Moroccans|Moroccan]], [[Egyptians|Egypt]]ian and [[Libyans|Libya]]n descent,{{cite tweet |author=Aja |user=ajaqueen |number=1016672512309067776 |date=July 10, 2018 |title=I‚Äôm Moroccan and Egyptian |archive-date=July 30, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180730155141/https://twitter.com/ajaqueen/status/1016672512309067776?s=21 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |dead-url=no}}{{cite tweet |author= Aja |user=ajaqueen |number=1016672588628676609 |date=July 10, 2018 |title=And a small percentage Libyan |archive-date=July 30, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180730155359/https://twitter.com/ajaqueen/status/1016672588628676609 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |dead-url=no}} and they identify as a [[person of color]].{{cite journal |last1=Cuby|first1=Michael|title=Aja Told Us the Backstory Behind Her Epic Death Drop on RuPaul's Drag Race: All Stars Season 3|url=https://www.them.us/story/aja-spills-the-tea-on-rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-3|accessdate=February 21, 2018|magazine=them. |publisher=Cond√© Nast |date=February 1, 2018 |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222044257/https://www.them.us/story/aja-spills-the-tea-on-rupauls-drag-race-all-stars-3 |dead-url=no}} They were adopted and raised by a single mother in Brooklyn. They used to suffer from [[Post-traumatic stress disorder|PTSD]] and [[anxiety]], attributing them to a "broken family" situation, but stopped having panic attacks after starting drag. Rivera resides in New York City.{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/strategist/article/rupauls-drag-race-aja-favorite-things.html |title=What Aja of 'RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars' Can't Live Without |first= |last=Aja |date=February 15, 2018 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |publisher=New York Media, LLC |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180219090448/http://nymag.com/strategist/article/rupauls-drag-race-aja-favorite-things.html |archive-date=February 19, 2018 |dead-url=no}} They lived as a trans woman for a year at age 18, later coming to identify as genderqueer after learning about non-binary identities. They use [[singular they]] pronouns.{{cite AV media | author=[[Peppermint (drag queen)|MissPepper Mint]] | date= May 5, 2017 |title=Rupaul's Drag Race Recap EP 7 with Peppermint (SPOILER ALERT) | medium=YouTube video |minutes=6:40 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xEq4XjIsWSU |quote=I identify by ''they'', ''them'', and ''their''. }} Just before filming season 9 of ''Drag Race'', Rivera was in a situation of [[domestic violence]] with a previous boyfriend.{{cite journal |last=Dresden |first=Hilton |title=Aja Spills on That Death Drop, Milk, & Why All Stars 3 is the Most 'Shocking' Season Yet |url=https://www.out.com/interviews/2018/2/08/aja-spills-death-drop-milk-why-all-stars-3-most-shocking-season-yet |access-date=February 21, 2018 |work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]] |publisher=Joe Landry |date=February 8, 2018 |issn=1062-7928 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222104831/https://www.out.com/interviews/2018/2/08/aja-spills-death-drop-milk-why-all-stars-3-most-shocking-season-yet |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |dead-url=no}} In December 2017, Rivera and their current boyfriend were kicked out of a [[Lyft]] after kissing.{{Cite news |url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2017/12/14/rupauls-drag-race-alum-aja-kicked-lyft-kissing-boyfriend/ |title='RuPaul's Drag Race' alum Aja kicked out of Lyft for kissing boyfriend |last=Cooper |first=Mariah |date=December 14, 2017 |newspaper=[[Washington Blade]] |publisher=Lynne Brown |access-date=February 21, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180222043853/http://www.washingtonblade.com/2017/12/14/rupauls-drag-race-alum-aja-kicked-lyft-kissing-boyfriend/ |archive-date=February 22, 2018 |dead-url=no}} The driver was later fired, and the company issued a statement of support for Aja. In August 2018, Aja was banned from Twitter for referring to a user who discounted their gender identity as a "senseless cow."{{cite news |url=https://www.gaytimes.co.uk/culture/111701/drag-race-star-aja-got-banned-from-twitter-for-calling-out-a-transphobe/ |title=Drag Race star Aja got banned from Twitter for calling out a transphobe |date=August 2, 2018 |last=Damshenas |first=Sam |access-date=August 28, 2018 |magazine=[[Gay Times]] |publisher=James Frost |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180802211232/https://www.gaytimes.co.uk/culture/111701/drag-race-star-aja-got-banned-from-twitter-for-calling-out-a-transphobe/ |archive-date=August 2, 2018 |dead-url=no}} Their account was reinstated after a few hours.{{Cite news|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/04/rupauls-drag-race-star-aja-banned-twitter-transphobes-attacked-7799226/ |title=RuPaul's Drag Race star Aja banned from Twitter after transphobes attacked them |date=August 4, 2018 |last=Pearce |first=Tilly |magazine=[[Metro (British Newspaper)|Metro]] |publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust|DMGT]] |access-date=August 25, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180826043930/https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/04/rupauls-drag-race-star-aja-banned-twitter-transphobes-attacked-7799226/ |archive-date=August 26, 2018 |dead-url=no}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Title ! scope="col" | Notes |- | 2017 !scope="row" | "Level Ya Pussy Up" | |- | 2017 !scope="row" | "C.L.A.T. January 1826 (aged 65) | death_place = | occupation = politician, landowner, inn-keeper, translator | nationality = [[Moldavia]]n | period = ca. 1790‚Äì1826 | genre = [[chronicle]], [[epic poetry]], [[lyric poetry]], [[satire]] | subject = | movement = [[Neoclassicism]], [[Romanticism]] | signature = | website = }} '''Alecu Beldiman''', common rendition of '''Alexandru Beldiman''' ([[Romanian Cyrillic alphabet|Romanian Cyrillic]]: A–ª—î—Øa–Ω–¥—Ä»¢ –ë—î–ª–¥–∏–ºa–Ω), also known as '''Alecul''' or '''Aleco Beldiman''' (1760‚Äìca. January 1826), was a [[Moldavia]]n statesman, translator and poet, one of the forerunners of [[Romanian nationalism]]. A scion of the [[Boyars of Wallachia and Moldavia|boyar elite]], he was the eldest son of ''[[Vornic]]'' Gheorghe Beldiman, and the nephew-in-law of chronicler [[Enache KogƒÉlniceanu]]. Alecu himself held high commission in the [[Moldavian military forces]] and bureaucracy, but secretly resented the [[Phanariote]] regime which had awarded them. He may have affiliated with a loose group known as the "[[National Party (Romania)|National Party]]", championing an alliance between Moldavia's independence from the [[Ottoman Empire]] and support for the [[French First Republic|French Republic]].
Beldiman's earliest contributions to cultural life probably date back to the 1790s, and originally included translations of French prose and [[Verse drama and dramatic verse|verse drama]]. He may have contributed an original play, while his brother, Dumitrache Beldiman, helped arrange some of the earliest Moldavian stage performances, as puppet shows. By 1820, Alecu had become the most productive translator in Moldavia, directly contributing to [[Westernization]] and the spread of [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment ideas]], and also completing a Romanian version of the ''[[Odyssey]]''. His works in the field were circulated in print form by [[Zaharia Carcalechi]], or otherwise copied by hand.
Beldiman's [[anti-Greek sentiment]] peaked during the 1821, when an invasion by the [[Sacred Band (1821)|Sacred Band]] chased him and other Romanian boyars out of Moldavia. The invasion and its violent aftermath inspired him to write the [[epic poem]] ''Tragodiea Moldovei'' ("Moldavia's Tragedy"). Although politically significant and comprising picturesque detail, the work was widely dismissed as a sample of exceptionally bad writing. Upon returning home, Beldiman also came into conflict with [[List of rulers of Moldavia|Prince]] [[Ioan Sturdza]], who had him imprisoned at [[TazlƒÉu Monastery]] in 1824. Poems he wrote during that interval show him as a conservative critic of republican and nationalist propaganda, and display his pity for the lower classes; he was also becoming more supportive of rule by the Ottoman Empire. Though eventually released, he maintained a low profile for the remainder of his life. His family continued to have a role in Moldavian, and later Romanian politics; his grandson [[Alexandru Beldiman]] was a journalist.
==Biography== ===Origins and early life=== According to family tradition, Beldiman's ancestors crossed into Moldavia from the [[Principality of Transylvania (1570‚Äì1711)|Principality of Transylvania]].<ref name="lu6alecu">{{ro icon}} Lauren»õiu Ungureanu, [https://web.archive.org/web/20180309165937/https://adevarul.ro/cultura/istorie/serial-boieri-mari-episodul-6-alecubeldiman-omul-ne-a-adus-adevarul-1_58a822785ab6550cb8954dbb/index.html "Boieri mari, episodul 6: Alecu Beldiman, omul care ne-a adus ''AdevƒÉrul''], in ''[[AdevƒÉrul]]'', February 18, 2017</ref><ref>Bacalov, p. 25; Iacob, p. 293</ref> This would make them distant relatives of the Hungarian Counts of Beldi.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> The immigrants entered historical record in March 1579, when "a certain Beldiman" served as Mayor (''[[Schulthei√ü|»òoltuz]]'') of [[Suceava]].<ref>Stoicescu, p. 349. See also Iacob, p. 293</ref> In April 1609, [[Nichifor Beldiman]], recorded in some genealogies as a ''neme»ô'' (untitled landowner), became ''[[Vornic]]''. He later served as [[Hetman]] and [[Logothete]],<ref>Stoicescu, pp. 349‚Äì350</ref> and, in late 1615, led the boyars into rebellion against Prince [[»òtefan IX Tom»ôa]]. He was captured in neighboring [[Wallachia]] and beheaded, his remains being disposed of in the [[Siret River]].<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Stoicescu, pp. 349‚Äì350, 353. See also Bacalov, pp. 88‚Äì89; CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Iacob, p. 293</ref> His two sons continued to hold major boyar ranks, while his daughter married into the PrƒÉjescu family.<ref>Stoicescu, pp. 350, 428</ref>
During the 18th century, the family lost its economic prosperity and political influence, and came to be regarded as emancipated peasants, rather than as boyars. Isolated in the rural areas of [[FƒÉlciu County]], they were often known by the nickname ''M√¢nja''.<ref>Iacob, pp. 293‚Äì295</ref> Alecu Beldiman's grandfather, Grigore M√¢nja Beldiman, rectified the situation. From beginnings as a [[Page (servant)|page]] at the court of Prince [[Constantin Cantemir]], he became fluent in [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]] in [[Istanbul]], where he also befriended ''[[Begzada|Beizadea]]'' [[Dimitrie Cantemir]].<ref>Iacob, p. 294</ref> In 1711, following the [[Pruth River Campaign]], the Cantemirs were chased out of the country; a Beldiman branch also left Moldavia and settled in the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>Bezviconi, p. 177</ref>
These events led to the emergence of a [[Phanariote]] regime in Moldavia and Wallachia: from ca. 1711, both [[Danubian Principalities]] had lost much of their autonomy within the [[Ottoman Empire]]; the boyar elite, formed mainly by [[Greeks in Romania|Greek immigrants]], controlled the administration. Grigore M√¢nja survived this time of troubles, and emerged as a favorite of the early Phanariotes: [[Nicholas Mavrocordatos]] and [[Grigore II Ghica]] both made used of his services. However, his participation in boyar conspiracies during the third reign of [[Mihai Racovi»õƒÉ]] endangered his career and his life.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Iacob, pp. 294‚Äì295</ref> Alecu's father was Gheorghe Beldiman (1724‚Äì1792). Orphaned of both parents by 1735, he and his four brothers were virtually adopted by the returning Prince Ghica, who groomed them for high office.<ref>Iacob, pp. 295‚Äì297</ref> Gheorghe amassed a personal fortune while climbing through the ranks, serving as ''[[Stolnic]]'' in 1763, ''[[Ban (title)|Ban]]'' in 1773, and finally ''Vornic'' in 1790.<ref>Iacob, pp. 297‚Äì298</ref> During the [[Russo-Turkish War (1768‚Äì1774)|Russo-Turkish War of the 1770s]], he declared his personal submission to [[Catherine the Great]].<ref>Ion Constantin, Ion Negrei, Gheorghe Negru, ''Ioan Pelivan: istoric al mi»ôcƒÉrii na»õionale din Basarabia'', p. 64. Bucharest: Editura Biblioteca Bucure»ôtilor, 2012. {{ISBN|978-606-8337-39-5}}</ref> He remained a noted figure in the [[Russophilia|Russophile]] party, and as a result earned a permanent appointment to the [[Sfatul boieresc|Moldavian Divan]] in 1774.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Iacob, p. 298</ref>
His son's birth came during the final stages of the Phanariote era. Alecu was born in 1760, either in [[Ia»ôi]], the Moldavian capital, or in the smaller town of [[Hu»ôi]].<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Densusianu, p. 27; Marcu, p. 119</ref> His maternal family was Greek.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> His mother, Maria, was the daughter of "publican Lefter" from Istanbul; her sister was married to [[Enache KogƒÉlniceanu]], the Moldavian chronicler and social reformer.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Iacob, p. 298. See also Marcu, p. 119</ref> The couple had an older daughter, Anastasia, and three younger sons: Iancu, Filip, and Dumitrache.<ref>Iacob, pp. 291, 298‚Äì300</ref>
[[File:Beldiman family coat of arms.svg|thumb|230px|Beldiman coat of arms]] Early on, Alecu became fluent in Greek and more unusually for his generation, also in French.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Eliade, p. 335; Marcu, pp. 121, 123</ref> He was educated at home and in private Greek schools‚Äîunlike Dumitrache, who was a graduate of the [[Princely Academy of Ia»ôi|Princely Academy]].<ref name="lu6alecu"/> He climbed steadily through the boyar hierarchy, becoming ''[[√áavu≈ü|Ceau»ô]]'' in the [[Moldavian military forces]] in 1785; he was ''[[Sardar|Serdar]]'' in 1789. At age 34, Alecu became a ''[[Paharnic]]'' at the princely court of [[Michael Drakos Soutzos]], before being moved to serve as ''[[Ispravnic]]'' in [[Neam»õ County]]. In 1800, under Prince [[Constantine Ypsilantis]], Beldiman was appointed ''[[Burgrave|P√¢rcƒÉlab]]'' of [[Gala»õi]].<ref name="Marcu, p. 119">Marcu, p. 119</ref> Following his father's death, he became sole owner of several estates. One was [[Miroslava, Ia»ôi|Corne»ôti]], outside Ia»ôi; two others, Iezereni and Te»õcureni, were in [[Bessarabia]].<ref>Iacob, pp. 301‚Äì304. See also Iorga (1912), p. 110</ref> Beldiman was married three times. His first wife, name unknown, was a member of the Romano clan; the second was Ileana, sister of the Logothete and poet [[Costache Conachi]], making him in-laws with [[Nicolae Vogoride]], future ''[[Kaymakam]]'' of Moldavia.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 55, 85, 980. See also Marcu, p. 119</ref> Beldiman's final, childless, marriage was to Elena Greceanu.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 55, 980</ref>
Researcher Nicolae N. Condeescu pushes the beginnings of Beldiman's literary activity into the 18th century, citing him as the uncredited translator of [[Vincent Voiture]]'s novel, ''Alcidales et Zelide''. In or around 1799, he also probably completed a version of [[Eustathios Makrembolites]] and [[Pierre-Fran√ßois Godard de Beauchamps|Godard de Beauchamps]]' ''Story of Hysmine and Hysminias''.<ref>Marcu, pp. 122‚Äì123</ref> In parallel, Beldiman became identified as one of the earliest contributors to the popularization of Western theater. The beginnings of Moldavian own theatrical activity are dated to ca. 1800, when Conachi, [[Nicolae Dimachi]] and Dumitrache Beldiman produced a short series of puppet shows, with Romanian-language texts.<ref name="tvteatru">Tatiana Vi»ôescu, "√énceputurile teatrului rom√¢nesc cult. Costachi Caragiali ‚Äì ''O repeti»õie moldoveneascƒÉ sau noi »ôi iar noi''", in ''Language and Literature ‚Äì European Landmarks of Identity'', Vol. 1, 2005, p. 129</ref> They also wrote a comedy of their own, making Dumitrache's one of Moldavia's first playwrights.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> Another play, tentatively dated to 1811, was called ''Serdarul din Orhei'' ("The ''Serdar'' of [[Orhei]]"); historian [[Nicolae Iorga]] believes that it was penned by Alecu Beldiman.<ref name="tvteatru"/>
Dumitrache and Alecu remained interested in both literature and politics; Filip withdrew to a monastery in 1792, while Iancu died later that same decade.<ref name="Iacob, pp. 299‚Äì300">Iacob, pp. 299‚Äì300</ref> According to philologist [[Gheorghe Bogdan-DuicƒÉ]], Alecu Beldiman's next translation was from [[Homer]]'s ''[[Odyssey]]'' (as ''Odiseia lui Omir''). Andreas Wolf, a [[Transylvanian Saxons|Transylvanian Saxon]] physician, met the Beldimans ca. 1797, praising them as lovers of arts and literature. Bogdan-DuicƒÉ hypothesizes that Beldiman handed his manuscript to Wolf, who took it to [[Sibiu|Hermannstadt]] and promised to publish it there.<ref>Lascu, pp. 99‚Äì101</ref> It shows the author's familiarity with, and reliance on, the French-style [[Romanization of Greek]], but is above all infused with staples of the [[Moldavian dialect]].<ref>Lascu, pp. 101‚Äì104</ref> Another similar text, tentatively attributed to Beldiman, showed up at [[Dorohoi]], near Moldavia's border with the [[Duchy of Bukovina]].<ref>Lascu, p. 99</ref>
===Literary fame=== An unclear tradition claims that one of the Belidimans was involved in a project to unite Wallachia and Moldavia as a single "republic", with help from [[Napoleon Bonaparte]].<ref>[[Nicolae Iorga]], "CugetƒÉtori rom√¢ni de acum o sutƒÉ de ani. I. Trei conservatori √Æn epoca de unire »ôi consolidare", in ''Memoriile Sec»õiunii Istorice'', Vol. XXI, 1939, pp. 706‚Äì707</ref> Following the [[Russo-Turkish War (1806‚Äì1812)|Russian invasion of Moldavia in 1806]], the youngest Beldiman brother interrupted his literary activities to serve in the occupation government.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> Alecu's own literary output became more notable following the [[Russo-Turkish War (1806‚Äì1812)|Russo-Turkish War]] and the [[Treaty of Bucharest (1812)|peace of Bucharest]]. Both Alecu Beldiman and Conachi had been chased out of their Bessarabian estates by the Russian occupation, which ultimately annexed the region as a [[Bessarabian Governorate]]; they settled in Ia»ôi as refugees.<ref>Bezviconi, p. 202</ref> In 1815, Prince [[Scarlat Callimachi (hospodar)|Scarlat Callimachi]] appointed Alecu an ''[[Agha (title)|Aga]]'' of his citadel in [[H√¢rlƒÉu]].<ref name="Marcu, p. 119"/> At around that time, he also became involved in the thriving business of inn-keeping, establishing his own taproom in [[B√¢rlad]].<ref>Marcel Proca, "Hanuri. Istoria evolu»õiei de la han la hotel", in ''Academia B√¢rlƒÉdeanƒÉ'', Vol. XXI, Issue 4 (57), Winter 2014, p. 15</ref> Beldiman was advanced to ''[[Postelnic]]'' in 1818, and finally became the ''Ispravnic'' of Ia»ôi in 1819, under Prince [[Michael Soutzos]].<ref>Marcu, p. 119. See also CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Densusianu, p. 27</ref> An 1819 map by Giuseppe Bayardi shows that he owned a mansion on Ia»ôi's S√¢rbeascƒÉ Street.<ref>Iftimi & VƒÉleanu, p. 45</ref> His estate grew to include parts of [[Zorleni|Popeni]] and [[Vinderei]], in [[Tutova County]], as well as several other townhouses in Ia»ôi. He also owned several hamlets populated by [[Romani people in Romania|Romanies]], which he kept as [[Slavery in Romania|boyar slaves]].<ref>Iacob, pp. 303‚Äì304</ref>
[[File:Íôû–≥—Äo–øa—Ä—£ –ª»¢–π A–≤—î–ª, 1818.png|thumb|280px|[[Cain and Abel|Abel]]'s burial, as illustrated in the 1818 edition of ''Moartea lui Avel'']] At this new stage, Beldiman blended [[Romanian nationalism]] with an interest in modern education, declaring himself a direct contributor to the "material progress of the Romanian people".<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Eliade, pp. 336, 348</ref> According to historian [[Neagu Djuvara]], Beldiman closely resembles the Wallachian intellectuals of his era, specifically [[Naum R√¢mniceanu]], [[Dionisie Eclesiarhul]], and [[Zilot Rom√¢nul]], in being virulently anti-Greek and anti-Phanariote.<ref>Djuvara, p. 88</ref> Scholar [[Pompiliu Eliade]] sees the Beldimans and the [[Sturdza family|Sturdzas]] as affiliates of the "[[National Party (Romania)|National Party]]", which favored independence from the Ottomans and sought direct protection from the [[French First Republic|French Republic]].<ref>Eliade, pp. 231‚Äì235, 248, 335</ref> However, Iorga also highlights the limits of Beldiman's nationalism: although he opted to stay in "Turkish Moldavia", he "never wrote as much as a verse, as much as a single line of prose" against Russian occupation in Bessarabia.<ref>Iorga (1912), p. 171</ref> Likewise, scholar [[Ovid Densusianu]] reads Beldiman as a Moldavian particularist, who was generally indifferent to the tribulations of Romanians in Wallachia and elsewhere.<ref>Densusianu, pp. 31‚Äì32</ref>
Philologist Andreea Giorgiana Marcu notes that, as a translator of Western literature, Beldiman was necessarily a participant in the [[Age of Enlightenment]]. He resonated most with [[Neoclassicism]], and especially with its "obviously moralizing" accounts.<ref>Marcu, pp. 119, 121, 123</ref> Likewise, culture critic [[George Panu]] proposes that Beldiman and Conachi must have been closely familiarized with, and imitators of, [[Johan Gabriel Oxenstierna]].<ref>Panu, p. 165</ref> Over 40 years, Beldiman arguably became the most prolific among Moldavia's contributors to Westernizing translations.<ref>Djuvara, pp. 309‚Äì310; Marcu, pp. 119, 121</ref> As noted by Densusianu, Beldiman translated plays that were never intended for actual stage production, since there was no Moldavian theater to speak of.<ref>Densusianu, pp. 28‚Äì29</ref> His texts had to introduce theatrical terminology for which there was yet no equivalent: he proposed ''obraz'' ("cheek" or "face") for "character", and ''schini'' for "scene".<ref>Marcu, p. 122</ref> However, Eliade proposes that Beldiman was directly inspired to write for the stage by witnessing Moldavia's first first-ever theatrical experiment, produced in December 1816 by [[Gheorghe Asachi]].<ref>Eliade, pp. 347‚Äì348</ref>
By late 1817, Beldiman had completed his own version of [[Voltaire]]'s ''Oreste'', which was only published in 1820.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Lascu, pp. 94‚Äì95; Eliade, p. 348</ref> He soon signed contracts with the Wallachian publisher, [[Zaharia Carcalechi]], who was active in the literary circles of [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526‚Äì1867)|Habsburg Hungary]].<ref>Densusianu, p. 27; Marcu, p. 119</ref> In 1818, Beldiman also put out ''√énvƒÉ»õƒÉturƒÉ sau povƒÉ»õuire pentru facerea p√¢inii'' ("A Guide or Advisor to Bread-making"), ultimately based on a text by Christian Albert R√ºckert, but directly translated from the Greek version penned by Dimitrios Samurkasis (Dimitrie Samurca»ô).<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Marcu, p. 121</ref> Also that year, Beldiman completed a translation of [[Salomon Gessner]]'s ''Der Tod Abels'', from the French intermediary. It was published at [[Buda]] as ''Moartea lui Avel''.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 55, 980; Densusianu, p. 27; Lascu, p. 94; Marcu, p. 121</ref>
Beldiman followed up in 1820 with ''Istoria lui Numa Pompilie''. This was a translation of [[Jean-Pierre Claris de Florian]]'s ''Numa Pompilius'', though Beldiman suppressed any mention of the real author.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55. See also Densusianu, p. 27; Eliade, pp. 336, 354‚Äì355, 416; Marcu, p. 121</ref> Its preface includes some of the earliest Romanian views on [[Translation studies|traductology]]: Beldiman complained about his struggles in adapting [[History of the Romanian language|early modern Romanian]] to render complex phrases in French.<ref>Eliade, pp. 354‚Äì355; Marcu, p. 123</ref> As noted by linguist [[Gheorghe IvƒÉnescu]], Beldiman followed [[Iacob Stamati]] and other Moldavians in adopting a [[Wallachian dialect|Wallachian spelling]] for some of his core vocabulary. ''Istoria'' consistently used ''giudecatƒÉ'' ({{IPA-ro|d íudekat…ô}}; "trial" or "judgement") for the Moldavianized ''judecatƒÉ'' ([ íudekat…ô]).<ref>[[Gheorghe IvƒÉnescu]], ''Probleme capitale ale vechii rom√¢ne literare'', pp. 62, 122. Ia»ôi: [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza University|Editura UniversitƒÉ»õii Alexandru Ioan Cuza]], 2012. {{ISBN|978-973-703-770-1}}</ref>
Beldiman completed numerous other translations, without ever submitting them for print. Various scribes copied them by hand, and they enjoyed popularity in boyar circles. However, Beldiman discovered that the texts were being slowly altered in the process, and decided to create his own authorized copies.<ref name="Marcu, p. 121">Marcu, p. 121</ref> This process involved several younger scribes. One was Ioni»õƒÉ Sion, who took dictation from Beldiman in writing "all sorts of verse and stories"; he was not paid for the job, but was allowed to make and keep his own copies.<ref name="Lascu, p. 101">Lascu, p. 101</ref> By 1813, Matei Gane of [[Vadu Moldovei|Ciumule»ôti]] had already collected and transcribed by hand Beldiman's various works.<ref>[[Constantin Gane]], ''Pe aripa vremei'', p. 72. Bucharest: Tipografia Steaua, 1923</ref> Beldiman penned, but never printed, other renditions of tragedies and stories by [[Antoine Fran√ßois Pr√©vost]] (with ''[[Manon Lescaut]]''), [[Sophie Ristaud Cottin|Madame Cottin]], [[Pietro Metastasio]], [[Ren√©-Charles Guilbert de Pix√©r√©court]], [[Jean-Fran√ßois Regnard]], [[Louis d'Ussieux]], and various unknown authors.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 55, 980; Carda»ô, p. x; Marcu, pp. 119, 121‚Äì122. See also Densusianu, pp. 27‚Äì28; Djuvara, pp. 309‚Äì310; Eliade, pp. 416‚Äì417; Lascu, ''passim''</ref> Reportedly, he also finished translated the ''[[Iliad]]'', but this work, if it ever existed, remains lost.<ref>Carda»ô, p. x; Lascu, pp. 94‚Äì95</ref>
===''Tragodiea Moldovei''=== The final stage of Beldiman's literary and political career was marked by the [[Greek War of Independence]], part of which was fought on Moldavian soil. In early 1821, the country was invaded by [[Alexander Ypsilantis]]' Greek forces, comprising the [[Filiki Eteria]] and the [[Sacred Band (1821)|Sacred Band]]. This occupation forced Beldiman out of Moldavia, and back into Bessarabia.<ref name="Densusianu, p. 27">Densusianu, p. 27</ref> The events, which culminated in an Ottoman incursion and a Greek defeat in the [[Battle of Dragashani]], were narrated by Beldiman in his rhyming chronicle. It is most often called ''Tragodiea Moldovei'' ("Moldavia's Tragedy"), but is also known as ''Eterie sau jalnicele scene prilejuite √Æn Moldova din resvrƒÉtirile grecilor, prin »ôeful lor Alexandru Ipsilanti venitu din Rusia la anul 1821'' ("The Eteria or Awful Scenes Occurring in Moldavia Because of the Rebellions by Greeks under Their Leader Alexander Ypsilantis, Who Came in from Russia in 1821"). According to literary historian [[George CƒÉlinescu]], the work was unintentionally "buffoonish", reading like a "humorous rigmarole".<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 53‚Äì55</ref> The overall result ran at 4,260 lines of verse which, CƒÉlinescu argues, was of an "old-fashioned type" and "monotonous", similar to later works by [[Constantin Negruzzi]].<ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 54, 210</ref>
[[File:AlexanderYpsilantisPruth.jpg|thumb|260px|[[Alexander Ypsilantis]] crossing the [[Prut River]] into Moldavia; allegory by [[Peter von Hess]]]] Scholar [[Gheorghe Carda»ô]] views Beldiman as the final Moldavian representative of a "prolix, untalented" school of poets, which began in 1681 with the anonymous ''Chronological Poem of the Moldavian Rulers''.<ref>Carda»ô, pp. ix‚Äìx</ref> Similarly, Densusianu notes that Beldiman demanded from his readers a patience that he never repaid. He was "not a poet, but only a versifier, and as such one in a string of mediocre writers." Moreover, his genre of choice, the "rhyming chronicle", was "unrewarding" and "manically" over-detailed, though he remained overall superior to Zilot, his Wallachian contemporary.<ref>Densusianu, pp. 29‚Äì30</ref> According to Eliade, ''Tragodiea'' is a "long and tedious newspaper article, prosaic as no prose has ever been, amusing only because the author himself realizes that his work is so very difficult, and his ability so very limited."<ref>Eliade, pp. 335‚Äì336</ref> Eliade also finds that, being no longer disciplined by foreign grammar (as he was in his translations), Beldiman constructs incoherent phrases. His vocabulary is "flooded" with Greek, [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman]], or [[Old Church Slavonic in Romania|Slavonic]] terms.<ref>Eliade, p. 355; Marcu, p. 123</ref>
According to historian [[Vlad Georgescu]], Beldiman was still notable as the most erudite chronicler of his generation.<ref>Georgescu, p. 174</ref> As CƒÉlinescu writes, an "entertaining jolt" in the epic came wherever Beldiman described his contempt for various of his contemporaries: the "godless dog" [[Vasileios Karavias]] and the haughty but "so very cowardly" [[Stefan Bogoridi]].<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 54</ref> Complex descriptions remain rare, as Beldiman often dismisses the Eterists and his other adversaries with just one epithet, sometimes bordering on the obscene.<ref>Densusianu, p. 30</ref> One line refers to a "Lividi Nicolaki, that base and ugly soul", who, according to Beldiman, had been appointed commander of Moldavia's Romanies by Ypsilantis' government. Researchers are unsure about whether this is a reference to [[Niccol√≤ Livaditti]], a [[Imperial Free City of Trieste|Triestene]] painter.<ref>Sorin Iftimi, Corina Cimpoe»ôu, Marcelina Br√Ændu»ôa Munteanu, ''Niccolo Livaditi »ôi epoca sa (1832‚Äì1858). ArtƒÉ »ôi istorie'', p. 21. Ia»ôi: [[Palace of Culture (Ia»ôi)|Palace of Culture]], 2012. {{ISBN|978-606-93119-6-7}}</ref>
Other aspects of the narrative were also polemical, reflecting Beldiman's brand of conservatism. In one episode of his epic, Beldiman sides with the [[Turks in Romania|local Turks]], whom the Eterist invasion had decimated.<ref name="Xenopol, p. 34">Xenopol, p. 34</ref> Another one of his stanzas lambasts [[Tudor Vladimirescu]], leader of the [[Wallachian uprising of 1821|parallel uprising in Wallachia]]. As noted by CƒÉlinescu, Beldiman and Vladimirescu were both Romanian nationalists, but of different visions; the Moldavian poet described the Wallachian revolutionist as "deceitful", prone to demagoguery.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55; Densusianu, p. 32. See also Georgescu, pp. 185‚Äì186</ref> Historian [[A. D. Xenopol]] also notes that Beldiman was sarcastic in his treatment of the Moldavian republican boyars, whom he called ''[[Decemviri]]''.<ref>Xenopol, p. 78</ref>
The restoration of Ottoman rule was rendered complete by the [[Battle of Sculeni|Eterist defeat at Sculeni]] in June 1821. Beldiman, having been appointed ''Vornic'',<ref>Georgescu, p. 169</ref> made the return trip to Ia»ôi. In November, he purchased the townhouse owned by a fellow boyar, the Wallachian [[Iordache Filipescu]], in PƒÉcurari neighborhood; it was here that he finished writing ''Tragodiea''.<ref name="Iftimi & VƒÉleanu, p. 26">Iftimi & VƒÉleanu, p. 26</ref> His poem-chronicle purposefully refrained from documenting the entirety of [[Ioan Sturdza]]'s reign, which began in 1822.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 54; Densusianu, p. 33</ref> One stanza circulates the notion that Sturdza was a "son of Moldavia", rather than a Phanariote, and expresses his belief that a "golden century" would follow.<ref>Densusianu, p. 31</ref> The ''Vornic'' soon returned to championing his version of boyar nationalism: in ''Tragodiea'', he makes explicit references to the "[[national interest]]".<ref>Georgescu, pp. 169, 182‚Äì184, 187, 189‚Äì190</ref> From 1823, Beldiman preserved a copy of what he claimed to be Moldavia's [[Capitulations of the Ottoman Empire|Capitulation]] to the Ottomans, outlining the ancient rights of its inhabitants. The text expanded on earlier forgeries.<ref>Georgescu, p. 186; Giurescu, pp. 4, 13‚Äì14, 19‚Äì22, 33‚Äì34</ref> Overall, he was more pro-Ottoman than Zilot and other chroniclers, being above all thankful that the Empire had defeated Ypsilantis.<ref>Georgescu, pp. 186‚Äì187</ref>
===Death and legacy=== In reality, Beldiman was at odds with the new regime. As one of the more conservative boyars, he clashed with the monarch. In March 1824, with Dimachi and others, he authored a letter of protest against Prince Sturdza, which was addressed to his overlord, [[List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire|Sultan]] [[Mahmud II]].<ref>PungƒÉ, p. 224</ref> During the same year, he was briefly imprisoned for his disobedience.<ref>Xenopol, p. 101</ref> Confined inside [[TazlƒÉu Monastery]], he produced his final set of poems, ''Stihuri'' ("Verse"). These are patriotic in tone, but noticeably skeptical of nationalism, explaining that, even though the Phanariotes had lost power, bad customs survived through native boyars; unusually in his context, he sided with the lower classes against the aristocrats.<ref>Densusianu, pp. 32‚Äì33</ref> Several lines refer to the harsh conditions faced by travelers, noting that rainstorms had rendered infernal his trip to TazlƒÉu.<ref>Ion Ionescu, "Podurile √Æn Rom√¢nia", in ''Natura. RevistƒÉ pentru RƒÉsp√¢ndirea »òtiin»õei'', Issue 4/1936, p. 7</ref> Stylistically, the ''Stihuri'' resemble both Neoclassicism and early [[Romantic poetry]], introducing elements later found in works by [[Barbu Paris Mumuleanu]].<ref name="Marcu, p. 120">Marcu, p. 120</ref>
Beldiman was ultimately released and made a discreet return to politics, living in relative seclusion for the rest of his life.<ref name="Densusianu, p. 27"/> His last published translation came out in 1824. It was a first volume of [[William Coxe (historian)|William Coxe]]'s ''Travels into Poland, Russia, Sweden and Denmark'', taken from a French version by [[Paul Henri Mallet]].<ref name="Marcu, p. 121"/> He died in January 1826, or at, earliest, December 1825<ref name="Iacob, p. 299">Iacob, p. 299</ref>‚Äîaccording to fellow writer Dimitrie Pastiescul, he still held a pen in his hand when this occurred.<ref name="Marcu, p. 119"/> Buried at his family's favorite church of [[Talpalari Church|Talpalari]],<ref name="lu6alecu"/> Beldiman left a large number of manuscripts, which were reportedly sold by the pound to a local collector.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 55</ref> Both Dumitrache and Filip survived their brother's death, the former dying in 1831.<ref name="Iacob, pp. 299‚Äì300"/> Filip, better known under his monastic name "Filaret", was appointed [[Archdiocese of Roman and BacƒÉu|Bishop of Roman]] and carateker of the [[Metropolis of Moldavia and Bukovina|Moldavian Metropolis]].<ref name="lu6alecu"/> In 1842, he served as administrator of Moldavia, filling in for Prince [[Mihail Sturdza]].<ref>PungƒÉ, p. 246</ref>
From his Romano marriage, Alecu had a daughter. Known as either Pulheria or Profira, she married into the [[Cantacuzino family]].<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 55, 980; Djuvara, p. 355; Iacob, p. 299</ref> She was famous for raising her husband's illegitimate son, the half-Romani DincƒÉ, who was formally her house slave. Her refusal to manumit him, and his subsequent suicide, resulted in mass support for abolitionism.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Djuvara, pp. 276‚Äì278</ref> Alecu's son, Vasile Beldiman, married a [[Mavrocordatos family|Mavrocordatos]].<ref name="ndi306">Narcis Dorin Ion, "Istorie »ôi genealogie. Convorbiri cu domnul Mihai Dim. Sturdza", in ''CercetƒÉri Istorice'', Vol. XXXIV, 2015, p. 306</ref><ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 980; Iacob, p. 299</ref> His only notable public office was that of Caretaker (''Epitrop'') of Moldavian schools.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> His wife Elena sold the Beldiman house in PƒÉcurari to boyar [[Lupu Bal»ô]]; it changed hands and served various functions until being demolished in 1966.<ref name="Iftimi & VƒÉleanu, p. 26"/>
Vasile died in 1853,<ref name="ndi306"/><ref name="Iacob, p. 299"/> and was survived by a son, [[Alexandru Beldiman]], who was the head of [[Romanian Police]] and close friend of the Principalities' first ''[[Domnitor]]'', [[Alexandru Ioan Cuza]]. In this capacity, he failed to prevent Cuza's toppling in 1866, and came to oppose the regime of [[Carol I of Romania|Carol I]], founding the left-wing newspaper ''[[AdevƒÉrul]]''.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> Corne»ôti, still owned by this branch of the family, was passed to poet [[Dimitrie Anghel]], and later to the Mavrocordatos.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Iacob, p. 303</ref>
A Iordachi Beldiman, sometimes described as Alecu's son,<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 162</ref> was in fact one of his nephews, born to Dumitrache Beldiman.<ref name="lu6alecu"/> Iordachi married Catinca Dimachi, daughter of the writer. She was made famous by her affair with poet [[Alexandru Hrisoverghi]]; according to one account, Hrisoverghi died after jumping out a window in Iordachi's townhouse.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>CƒÉlinescu, pp. 93, 162‚Äì163</ref> Also a ''Vornic'', Iordachi was noted for commissioning a gallery of portraits of Moldavian Princes.<ref>Sorin Iftimi, "Chipurile domnitorului Alexandru Moruzi √Æn portrete din secolul XIX", in ''CercetƒÉri Istorice'', Vol. XXXIV, 2015, p. 179</ref> During the [[United Principalities]] era, he became a leading figure in Ia»ôi's conservative circles, helping [[Iacob Negruzzi]] establish the political review ''Constitu»õiunea''.<ref name="lu6alecu"/><ref>Iorga (1934), p. 62</ref> Alecu's niece, Maria or Marghioala, was a locally famous philanthropist,<ref name="lu6alecu"/> married to politician [[Scarlat Miclescu]]. Their son, Dimitrie S. Miclescu (1820‚Äì1896), participated in the [[Moldavian revolution of 1848|1848 revolutionary movement]], as well as being a published poet. He became a noted agitator on the far-left of [[Liberalism and radicalism in Romania|Romanian liberalism]] and renounced all claim to boyar privilege, including his family name.<ref>"Dumitru Scarlat Miclescu", in ''[[Gazeta Transilvaniei]]'', Issue 270/1896, p. 5</ref>
Beldiman's translations continued to be read by young intellectuals in all Romanian-speaking areas: [[Constantin N. BrƒÉiloiu]], who went abroad to study in 1828, ordered copies of ''Oreste'' and ''Istoria lui Numa Pompilie'', "so as not to forget his language".<ref>Lauren»õiu Vlad, "C√¢teva date despre educa»õia unui t√¢nƒÉr boier valah. Studiile lui Constantin N. BrƒÉiloiu la Sibiu, Geneva »ôi Paris √Æn anii 1822‚Äì1832", in ''»öara B√¢rsei'', Issue 8, 2009, p. 50</ref> Ioni»õƒÉ Sion's manuscripts were preserved by his son, the poet-memoirist [[Gheorghe Sion]].<ref name="Lascu, p. 101"/> For decades, ''Tragodiea'' circulated in 23 handwritten copies, two of which were respectively owned by [[Nicolae BƒÉlcescu]] and [[Alexandru Odobescu]].<ref name="Marcu, p. 120"/> In the 1840s, [[Mihail KogƒÉlniceanu]] set himself the task of printing Beldiman's writings and documents as part of an anthology.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 177; Giurescu, pp. 4, 13, 19‚Äì20</ref> As ''Eterie sau jalnicele scene'', ''Tragodiea'' was eventually printed in 1861, at the expense of an Alecu Balica; it was reissued in 1875 as ''Tragedia Moldovei''.<ref>CƒÉlinescu, p. 980. See also Densusianu, p. 29; Marcu, p. 120</ref>
By then, poet [[Vasile Alecsandri]] was actively campaigning for Beldiman to be included into the Romanian literary canon,<ref>Iorga (1934), pp. 179‚Äì180</ref> while philologist [[Alexandru Lambrior]] unsuccessfully proposed to set the Romanian literary standard exclusively on words used by Beldiman and Conachi.<ref>Panu, pp. 171‚Äì173</ref> Beldiman's work was finally rediscovered in the 1890s. One of its promoters was the antiquarian [[George Ionescu-Gion]], who insisted that Beldiman was without philosophical merit, but a genuine patriot.<ref>Rodica Florea, "Reviste »ôi scriitori √Æn ultimele douƒÉ decenii ale secolului al XIX-lea", in [[»òerban Cioculescu]], [[Ovidiu Papadima]], [[Alexandru Piru]] (eds.), ''Istoria literaturii rom√¢ne. III: Epoca marilor clasici'', p. 945. [[File:Angela Cannings.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Angela Cannings outside the [[Palace of Westminster]].]] '''Angela Cannings''' was wrongfully convicted and sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] in 2002 for the murder of her seven-week-old son, Jason, who died in 1991, and of her 18-week-old son Matthew, who died in 1999. Her first child, Gemma, died of [[Sudden Infant Death Syndrome]] (SIDS) in 1989 at the age of 13 weeks, although she was never charged in connection with Gemma's death.
Her conviction was based on claims that she had smothered the children, but was overturned as unsafe by the [[Court of Appeal of England and Wales|Court of Appeal]] on 10 December 2003.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/wiltshire/3306271.stm "Mother cleared of killing sons"], BBC News, December 10, 2003.</ref> Cannings was convicted after the involvement in her case of Professor Sir [[Roy Meadow]], a paediatrician who was later struck off, then reinstated, by the General Medical Council.<ref>Doward, Jamie. [http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,6903,1391441,00.html "Parents demand gag on cot death doctor's lectures"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223053743/http://observer.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0%2C6903%2C1391441%2C00.html |date=February 23, 2007 }}, ''The Observer'', January 16, 2005.</ref>
The Cannings case was re-examined after a [[BBC]] "Real Story" investigation showed that her paternal great-grandmother had suffered one sudden infant death and her paternal grandmother two. Professor Michael Patton, a clinical geneticist at St George's Hospital Medical School, told the BBC that a genetic inheritance was the most likely explanation for the crib deaths in the family.<ref name=BBCNov2>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/real_story/3234297.stm "Doubts case over baby deaths case"], BBC News, November 2, 2003.</ref>
==Involvement of Roy Meadow== Expert witness Professor Sir [[Roy Meadow]] was later struck off the [[General Medical Council]] register partly as a result of his evidence at the Cannings trial. Meadow based his calculations on the likelihood of a second [[cot death]] being the same as the likelihood of a first, whereas in households where one crib death has taken place, the [[probability]] of another is greatly increased. He also asserted cot death implausible (which was contrary to the opinion of other specialists). Cannings later said Meadow should be "severely punished" for his testimony in her case and others. Meadow was later reinstated to the GMC on appeal, a judge ruling that his errors did not amount to serious professional misconduct.<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1510798/Sir-Roy-Meadow-the-flawed-witness-wins-GMC-appeal.html</ref>
==Other cases== The quashing of Cannings' conviction and other high-profile cases resulted in a review of 297 other cases where conviction relied on expert witness opinion. On 14 February 2006, [[Lord Goldsmith]], the [[Attorney General for England and Wales|Attorney General]], announced that three of these cases needed to be reconsidered by the courts, but that the majority did not give rise to concern.

'''Bautista van Schouwen Vasey''' (San Lorenzo de Tarapac√°, [[Chile]], 3 April 1943 - [[Santiago de Chile]], 13 December 1973) was a medical doctor and one of the founders of the [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|Movement of the Revolutionary Left]] (MIR), the Chilean guerrilla organization which earliest resisted the Military Coup of Augusto Pinochet in 1973. Five among the "Ten most wanted" opposition figures wanted by the military government after the 11 September coup were militants of MIR. Bautista van Schouwen was at the time member of MIR's "Comisi√≥n Pol√≠tica" and the "Secretariado", the highest executive organ of the MIR. The military had set a reward of 500 000 Escudos to anyone who would lead them to the capture of Van Schouwen.<ref>Diario "El Mercurio", Santiago, Chile, 28 Septembre 1973</ref> He was abducted in Santiago December 13, 1973, in the church ''Parroquia Capuchinos'' (2345 Catedral Street), after having been caught when the priest who was sheltering them, unwittingly let slip to his military cousins, that they were at the church. Father Enrique White was also detained and tortured, later exiled to England.<ref>Nancy Guzm√°n Jasme, "Un grito desde el silencio: detenci√≥n, asesinato y desaparici√≥n de Bautista van Schouwen y Patricio Munita". [[LOM Ediciones]], Santiago, 1998, page 153-</ref> Van Schouwen and his lieutenant Patricio Munita had previously obtained clandestine refuge in the Capuchinos church-premises. They were soon after their capture killed under torture in the Army-managed detention and torture centre of [[Villa Grimaldi]]. The assassinations of Van Schouwen and Munita were however concealed by the Pinochet government and the Van Schouwen case during several years labelled as ''[[Forced disappearance#Argentina|desaparecido]]'' (the "missing ones") by Human-rights organizations in Chile (see below Demise whereabouts).
== Biography == Bautista van Schouwen Vasey was the first son of Industrial Chemical Engineer Bautista van Schouwen Figueroa and Carlota Mar√≠a Valentina Vasey Crozier. He had two younger brothers named Carlos and Jorge. The family arrived in the Concepci√≥n region in 1953 and established first in a rural property in the nearby La Florida and then in Concepci√≥n. During the second half of his high-school studies he met [[Miguel Enr√≠quez (politician)|Miguel Enriquez]] and [[Marcello Ferrada de Noli]]. These friends,<ref>Christopher Minster (2009) ''Chile's MIR: The Revolutionary Left Movement. Urban Guerrillas Declare War on the Pinochet Dictatorship''. About.com: Latin American History [http://latinamericanhistory.about.com/od/thehistoryofchile/a/09ChileMIR.htm]</ref> together with an elder brother of Miguel Enr√≠quez (Marco Antonio) and a new comrade they met at the first year of medical studies at the [[University of Concepcion]] (Jorge Guti√©rrez Correa) started the secret group Movimiento Socialista Revolucionario in 1962. Other two members joined 1963-1964. The group first entered the socialist cell "Sierra Maestra" (also called "Espartaco", of the Socialist Party Youth in Concepci√≥n) led by Marcello Ferrada de Noli <ref>Pedro Naranjo, "La vida de Miguel Enr√≠quez y el MIR". En: Naranjo P., Ahumada M., Garc√©s M y Pinto J. ''Miguel Enr√≠quez y el proyecto revolucionario en Chile''. Ed. Lom, 2004. Page 37</ref> and who have according to their plans established earlier a "pie de terre" in the Socialist Party 1961. In fact, the group was from the beginning a fraction within the Socialist Party in Concepci√≥n. Historians have referred that this political group developed around their publication "Revolution" which first issue appeared in 1963.<ref>Julio Cesar Jobet. "Historia del Partido Socialista de Chile". Cuadernos de Orientaci√≥n Socialista. Santiago de Chile, 2003. Primera edici√≥n digital 2003 [http://www.salvador-allende.cl/Biblioteca/ps_jobet.pdf]</ref>
Bautista van Schouwen Vasey married in the summer of 1968 to In√©s Enr√≠quez Espinosa, an English literature graduate and the only sister of Miguel Enr√≠quez Espinosa, the best man of their wedding was their other old-time friend Marcello Ferrada de Noli. Bautista van Schouwen Vasey and In√©s Enr√≠quez Espinosa had one child named Pablo.
In October 1965 Bautista van Schouwen Vasey participated in the foundation of the MIR in Santiago and was elected at that opportunity member of MIR's Central Committee.<ref>Pedro Alfonso Vald√©s Navarro (2008) "Elementos te√≥ricos en la formaci√≥n y desarrollo del MIR durante el periodo 1965-1970". Universidad de Valpara√≠so, Chile. Tesis de grado. Pages 1-121 [http://www.archivochile.com/tesis/04_tp/04tp0016.pdf]</ref> Two years after was elected chairman of MIR's Regional Committee for Concepci√≥n, the largest in the MIR, nationwide. In 1966 he was President of the Medical Student Union of the University of Concepci√≥n and led with Nelson Gutierrez (President of the Sociology Students Union), Marcello Ferrada de Noli (President of the Philosophy Students Union) and Luis Moreno (President of the Engineer Students Union) a long, and at times bloody, struggle for a university reform at the conservative University of Concepci√≥n. Together with medical student Luciano Cruz (another notorious MIR leader, died 1971) and other students of prominent participation in such struggle ‚Äì mainly from the ''Movimiento Universitario de Izquierda, MUI'' - they finally succeeded in 1968 obtaining a university reform which became model for the student movement in the country elsewhere. Years 1968-1969 the student-movement in Chile had scored notable victories but at the same time increased a confrontation with the authorities both at the universities and government. It was at that time when Bautista Van Schouwen Vasey and Miguel Enr√≠quez Espinosa published the document ''De las luchas estudiantiles a las filas de la Revoluci√≥n'' ("From the students' struggles to the ranks of the Revolution").
In 1969 the Christian Democratic government of [[Eduardo Frei Montalva|Eduardo Frei]] declared MIR out-law and many MIR cadres had to pass to clandestine life. The government implemented a nationwide persecution of the thirteen most known leaders of the organization at that epoch (among those wanted were Miguel Enr√≠quez, Luciano Cruz, Bautista Van Schouwen, Nelson Gutierrez, Marcello Ferrada de Noli, Anibal Matamala, Jose Bordas, Jos√© Go√±i, Juan Saavedra Gorriategy, and others).<ref>Diario "El Mercurio", Santiago de Chile, "A Trav√©s de la Historia Terrorista del Movimiento de Izquierda Revolucionaria (MIR)", 25 August 1973</ref> Bautista Van Schouwen was however never captured. The cause against the MIR was eventually dismissed the year after by the new government of Salvador Allende through an amnesty decree. By then Bautista Van Schouwen had moved to Santiago and had taken the political leadership and the editor-in-chief post of ''El Rebelde'', MIR's official newspaper.
Bautista van Schouwen Vasey graduated in 1968 from medical school with the second best marks of his promotion and he took afterwards an internship and postdoctoral training in neurology. He left those activities shortly thereafter for full-time dedication to the political and military activities of MIR, in preparation to resist the imminent [[1973 Chilean coup d'√©tat]] against the [[Salvador Allende]] government which finally took place on the 11th of September, 1973. Some time before in 1972 Bautista Van Schouwen Vasey was married for the second time to Astrid Heitmman, a registered nurse at the university hospital.
== Ideological stands == The ideological stands among the early generation of youngsters from Concepci√≥n that founded MIR in 1965 correspond to a variety of political ideologies ranging from Social-liberalism to Marxist and Trotskyite positions. Although official declarations of the epoch, MIR had not a truly uniform ideological stand until the Congress of 1967 (see [[Revolutionary Left Movement (Chile)|Movement of the Revolutionary Left]]) in which prevailed the Leninists positions represented by the new elected General Secretary Miguel Enriquez. Bautista Van Schouwen did follow his friend Miguel Enr√≠quez in this regard. However, it has been put forward that van Schouwen would have been a closer follower to the doctrine of [[Rosa Luxemburg]], favouring general strikes over cadre-organization political work as in Leninists traditions.<ref>Pedro Alfonso Vald√©s Navarro (2008) "Elementos te√≥ricos en la formaci√≥n y desarrollo del MIR durante el periodo 1965-1970". Universidad de Valpara√≠so, Chile. Tesis de grado. Pages 1-121 [http://www.archivochile.com/tesis/04_tp/04tp0016.pdf]</ref> Other authors of the epoch have placed Van Schouwen's earlier ideological positions in the line of socialist humanism and also sympathetic with social-anarchist positions. Contrary to what "official" versions have maintained,<ref>i.e. Naranjo Sandoval, Pedro; "La vida de Miguel Enr√≠quez y el MIR", in Naranjo Sandoval, Pedro (ed); Miguel Enr√≠quez y el Proyecto Revolucionario en Chile. Ed. LOM. Santiago, 2004. p. 44</ref> historians have established ‚Äì based in interview testimonies of Marco Antonio Enr√≠quez, a History Professor at [[Sorbonne]] ( also referred above as elder brother of Miguel Enr√≠quez) - that Bautista Van Schouwen did not participate in the elaboration of the first historical document in the foundation of MIR, The "Insurrectional Thesis".<ref>[http://www.archivochile.com/tesis/04_tp/04tp0016.pdf Pedro Alfonso Vald√©s Navarro (2008), cited work above, page 121]</ref> Bautista Van Schouwen was nevertheless a prolific writer of political documents and he was trusted by his peers the political and ideological leadership of MIR's official newspaper "El Rebelde". The last known MIR-document in which Bautista Van Schouwen had personally participated was the situation-analysis of December 1973 authored by the ''Secretariado'' of MIR (the MIR executive committee, led by [[Miguel Enr√≠quez (politician)|Miguel Enr√≠quez]]).
== Demise whereabouts == Bautista Van Schouwen was killed under captivity by DINA late at night December 13, 1973 with a bullet on the head; later abandoned under a tree, at a cross-road in the proximities of [[Villa Grimaldi]], and again his body perforated from the back with multiple bullets from machine-gun fire. Another military patrol discovered later the corpses of Munita and Van Schouwen (with no identifications) and ‚Äì unaware of the above facts ‚Äì took them routinely to the Forensic station in Santiago. There was an autopsy performed, and the victim's identities were also established, which was routinely reported thereafter to the police. When this report reached DINA their operatives confiscated the corpses and ordered a secret burial, at night, in [[Patio 29]] at the "Cementerio General" of Santiago. On the 16 February 1974, again in a secret operation ‚Äì this time presumably under the direct orders of Augusto Pinochet to General Ernesto Baeza, the Interior Minister <ref>Nancy Guzm√°n Jasme, "Un grito desde el silencio: detenci√≥n, asesinato y desaparici√≥n de Bautista van Schouwen y Patricio Munita". Lom Ediciones, Santiago, 1998. Page 133 -</ref>- DINA arranged the exhumation and incineration of Bautista Van Schouwen's remains. The secret killing of Bautista Van Schouwen had remarkable consequences.
The MIR let it be known for many years that Van Schouwen was instead alive, under captivity by the military, but heavily wounded due to torture. MIR even published a picture of Van Schouwen depicting him with bandages supposedly imprisoned in a military medical compound. On the other hand, the military have given contradictory information to the public; first the interior ministry informed, and echoed by the press <ref>Diario "El Mercurio", Santiago, Chile, 17 August 1974</ref> (17 August 1974) that Bautista Van Schouwen had been captured on December 13, 1973, and that he was "in custody at an undisclosed location".<ref>Mark Ensalaco, "Chile under Pinochet. Recovering the truth". University of Pennsylvania Pres, Philadelphia, 2000. Page 72 [https://books.google.com/books?id=hzrwMb3UppYC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=bautista+van+schowen&source=bl&ots=-72BwaxLr9&sig=rJnVH1au9HfEip3RbOR6rYmTuEU&hl=sv&ei=3IQATqm0DsaCOqTuzaIO&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=15&ved=0CHYQ6AEwDg#v=onepage&q=MIR&f=false]</ref> Later that year the military retracted the information on that Van Schouwen was in custody in Chile and affirmed instead that he had "escaped to Cuba on the 2nd of February" 1974.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=hzrwMb3UppYC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=bautista+van+schowen&source=bl&ots=-72BwaxLr9&sig=rJnVH1au9HfEip3RbOR6rYmTuEU&hl=sv&ei=3IQATqm0DsaCOqTuzaIO&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=15&ved=0CHYQ6AEwDg#v=onepage&q=MIR&f=false Mark Ensalaco, quoted work. Page 72]</ref> Nevertheless, [[Amnesty International]] informed in their first report about the human-rights violations by the Chilean Junta that Van Schouwen was held prisoner and had been transported to a variety of detention sites by the military. The Chilean human-rights organizations, for their part, for years went on demanding clarity on the "disappearance" of Bautista Van Schouwen and his case was included in a variety of judicial processes that ensued around the missing ones in Chile (those whose whereabouts were unknown). As late as 1998 his friend and MIR co-founder Marcello Ferrada de Noli, then a university professor in Norway, filled in European courts a criminal case against Augusto Pinochet <ref>[http://ferradanoli.files.wordpress.com/2009/12/ferrada-noli-bring-pinochet-to-justice2.pdf Svenska Dagbladet, Stockholm, 06-11-1998. Br√§nnpunkt, page 10]</ref> for the assassination or disappearance of Bautista Van Schouwen and Edgardo Enriquez.<ref>Associated Press, November 1, 1998. "Chilean in Norway files against Pinochet". OSLO, Norway, November 1 (AP)</ref><ref>[http://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/1998/11/01/137778.html NTB/Dagblad, "Pinochet politianmeldt i Norge", Oslo, 1 Nov 1998]</ref> Pinochet was then under house arrest in London but was ultimately granted by the British government returning to Chile without processes in Europe.
In 2007 an Appeal Court in Santiago de Chile processed the former DINA commander, Army General (R) [[Marcelo Moren Brito]], for the criminal killing of Bautista Van Schouwen and his lieutenant Patricio Munita.<ref>Diario "La Naci√≥n", Santiago, Chile, 25 July 2007</ref>
In 2013 Bautista's son Pablo began legal proceedings against the Chilean state in a civil action. The court hearing with full witness testimonies began on January 31, 2017 in Santiago.
