'''James Chau''' (Chinese: Âë®Êü≥Âª∫Êàê ''Zh≈çuli«î'' ''Ji√†nch√©ng''{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}) who was born on 11 December 1977,<ref name="james-chau.com about">{{cite web|url=http://www.james-chau.com/about/ |title=About |publisher=James Chau |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> is a [[journalist]], television presenter, and United Nations [[Goodwill Ambassador]]. He anchors the main evening news on [[China Central Television]], which broadcasts from [[Beijing]] to more than 80 countries, and reports live on location worldwide.<ref>http://www.st-edmunds.cam.ac.uk/alumni/newsletter/St%20Edmund's%20Edition%20No.%203.pdf</ref> As a correspondent, he has covered breaking news on the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|Asian tsunami]]<ref name="British Council GG4 speakers">{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcouncil.org/goingglobal-gg4-speakers-james-chau.htm |title=James Chau ‚Äì Speakers ‚Äì Going Global 4 |publisher=British Council |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and global [[SARS]] outbreak,<ref name="British Council GG4 speakers"/> and has interviewed world figures: [[UN Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDX2GHRnqXs ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140609034724/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vDX2GHRnqXs |date=9 June 2014 }}</ref> [[Nobel Laureate]] [[Fran√ßoise Barr√©-Sinoussi]],<ref name="youtube.com">{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h3lfpa4eTZM |title=James Chau Interviews... Noble Prize Winner Fran√ßoise Barr√©-Sinoussi |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and [[King Constantine II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cctv.com/program/worldinsight/20051228/101649.shtml |title=CCTV International |publisher=Cctv.com |date=28 December 2005 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> He is one of the few journalists to have interviewed Zimbabwean President [[Robert Mugabe]] and mathematics teacher [[Anand Kumar]].,<ref name="jameschau2004">{{cite web|url=http://sites.google.com/site/jameschau2004/ |title=jameschau2004 |publisher=Google |date=8 June 2006 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="english.cntv.cn">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/education/in-china-super-30-maths-wizard-sees-a-lesson-for-india/article2889936.ece|title=In China, ‚ÄòSuper 30' Maths wizard sees a lesson for India |accessdate= 14 February 2012 | location=Chennai, India|work=The Hindu|first=Ananth|last=Krishnan|date=14 February 2012}}</ref> In 2009, he was appointed by the United Nations as China's first [[UNAIDS]] Goodwill Ambassador.<ref name="unaids.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/Partnerships/Advocacy+partners/SpecRep/UNAIDS_National_Goodwill_Amb_JamesChau.asp |title=Partnerships Department |publisher=Unaids.org |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
== Education == Chau was born in [[England]] and educated at [[City of London School]]<ref>[http://jcc.org.uk/members-news/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090905220813/http://jcc.org.uk/members-news/ |date=5 September 2009 }}</ref> and Cambridge University, where he was ''[[Varsity (Cambridge)|Varsity]]'' News Features Editor.<ref name="James Chau CCTV UN Millennium summit">{{cite web|url=http://english.cntv.cn/reporter/james/un/index.shtml |title=CCTV reporter James Chau in UN Millennium summit ‚Äì Interview Video |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> He also studied piano at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] under Professor Graeme Humphrey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.123people.com/s/graeme+humphrey |title=Graeme Humphrey ‚Äì Email, Address, Phone numbers, everything! |publisher=123people.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> In interviews, he has cited the photographer [[Lord Snowdon]] for encouraging him as a writer,<ref name="shmag">{{cite web|url=http://www.shmag.cn/feature/first_person_james_chau |title=SH Magazine: Shanghai restaurants, events and nightlife | SH Magazine Online |publisher=Shmag.cn |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and guiding him to his first journalistic internship at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''. His parents were born in Indonesia and Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lt.radio86.com/node/27793 |title=I Am Broadcasting From China - All about China | Radio86.com |publisher=Lt.radio86.com |date=19 October 2011 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
== Television == After graduating from Cambridge, and interning at ''Vogue'' and [[Mirror Group Newspapers]],<ref name="shmag"/> he moved to [[Hong Kong]] for his first newsroom position. From 2001 he was a reporter and later an anchor at [[TVB Pearl]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cctv.com/english/special/C12203/01/index.shtml |title=CCTV-English Channel-James Chau |publisher=Cctv.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> His first major story was in Washington where Hong Kong Chief Executive [[Tung Chee-Hwa]] met for talks with U.S. President [[George W. Bush]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cctv.com/english/special/C12203/20040430/101784.shtml |title=CCTV-English Channel-James Chau |publisher=Cctv.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> Chau returned to the White House a year later with Chinese leader [[Hu Jintao]] and was the only foreign journalist to cover all seven cities in what was the incoming President's debut overseas tour.<ref name="British Council GG4 speakers"/> During a reporting assignment to the [[World Trade Organization]] in Geneva on 11 September 2001, he flew to London to cover the international reaction to the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center in New York.<ref>http://www.icaap9.org/userfiles/Bio%20-%20James%20Chau.pdf</ref> While promoted to anchor the news, he continued to report on the bird flu outbreak, the [[Doha Ministerial Conference]] where China was accepted as a WTO member, and the SARS pandemic that took him to outbreak areas in Hong Kong, Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur.<ref name="james-chau.com about"/>
Chau joined China Central Television in 2004,<ref name="jameschau2004"/> where he features primarily as a main presenter on the 24-hour CCTV News English-language station. Since April 2010, he also co-fronts the channel's flagship ''China 24'' show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/china24/01/index.shtml |title=China Central Television |publisher=English.cntv.cn |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> He is one of the first foreign anchors to anchor the evening program for the state broadcaster that, across its various channels combined, draws an audience share of 1.2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/results?start=30&endeca=1&return=endeca&D=11%2F05%2F2008&Nty=1&N=4294966457&Ns=P_Ranking%7c1 |title=November 5, 2008 | Fast Facts |publisher=Adage.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> His breaking stories include the suicide of former South Korean President [[Roh Moo-hyun]], [[2008 Sichuan earthquake|Sichuan earthquake]], and the [[Indian General Election, 2009|2009 Indian elections]]. In the run-up to the Beijing Olympics, he taped a television special on the Great Wall of China with the Australian actress and singer, [[Olivia Newton-John]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jmnM-p4v-9M |title=James Chau Interviews... Olivia Newton-John |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> During the Games, he anchored the morning show for the official Olympic broadcaster.<ref name="james-chau.com about"/> His two-hour coverage of the live standoff where eight Hong Kong tourists died in the [[Manila hostage crisis]] was noted in the ''[[Guardian newspaper|Guardian]]'' for the openness of this coverage in the Chinese state media.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathan Watts |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/23/manila-bus-siege-hostages-philippines-china |title=At least eight dead in Philippines as siege ends with police storming bus | World news |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=25 October 2011 |date=23 August 2010}}</ref> He continues to report on location for the Asian tsunami in Indonesia, [[International AIDS Conference]] in Vienna, and [[UN General Assembly]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.cntv.cn/reporter/james/index.shtml |title=James Chau, UNAIDS Goodwill Ambassador for China ‚Äì CCTV Host and Reporter |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and [[Millennium Development Goals]] Summit in New York.<ref name="James Chau CCTV UN Millennium summit"/>
He writes a newspaper column for the [[Global Times]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://opinion.globaltimes.cn/commentary/2010-09/577798_2.html |title=Aids won't wait for the recession to finish ‚Äì GlobalTimes |publisher=Opinion.globaltimes.cn |date=27 September 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://opinion.globaltimes.cn/foreign-view/2010-08/568525.html |title=Manila's botched bus rescue leaves a bad taste behind |work=Global Times |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
== UNAIDS Goodwill Ambassador == Chau has been described as one of China's leading AIDS activists.<ref name="unaids.org.cn">http://unaids.org.cn/uploadFiles/2009121808551558.pdf</ref><ref>http://unaids.org.cn/uploadFiles/2009111213035034.pdf</ref> He came under the early mentorship of Belgian scientist [[Peter Piot]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shenzhen.urbanatomy.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=302:secrets-a-lies-cctvs-james-chau&catid=144:features&Itemid=12 |title=that's PRD | Listings, Events, Reviews, Jobs |publisher=Shenzhen.urbanatomy.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> who co-discovered the [[Ebola]] virus, and has traveled on health missions to India, Norway, Indonesia, and the United States.<ref name="unaids.org"/> In August 2009, the United Nations announced his appointment as its first UNAIDS Goodwill Ambassador on the Chinese Mainland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cctv.com/english/special/excl/20090814/110009.shtml |title=CCTV news anchor James Chau nominated "UNAIDS Goodwill Ambassador" CCTV-International |publisher=Cctv.com |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> joining [[Naomi Watts]], [[Michael Ballack]] and [[Princess Stephanie of Monaco]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/Partnerships/Advocacy+partners/SpecRep/default.asp |title=Partnerships Department |publisher=Unaids.org |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> In April 2010, his first show as presenter of the new ''China 24'' program was headlined by China's lifting of the HIV-related travel ban,.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uaat-XhJoNw |title=James Chau Reports... China Lifts HIV Travel Ban |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
As UNAIDS Goodwill Ambassador, he has been featured in ''[[GQ]]'' and ''[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]'',<ref name="unaids.org.cn"/> and partners with leading Chinese internet portal, [[Sohu.com]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gongyi.sohu.com/20091128/n268541563.shtml |title=ÊêúÁãê‰∏æÂäûËâæÊªãÁóÖÊó•‰∏ªÈ¢òÊ¥ªÂä® ÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÂèóËâæÊªãÂΩ±ÂìçÂ≠©Â≠ê-ÂÖ¨ÁõäÈ¢ëÈÅì |publisher=Gongyi.sohu.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> In 2008, he was named to the inaugural Young Leaders Summit at the [[Google]] headquarters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aids2031.org/youngleaderssummit |title=Our2031 ‚Äì Blog |publisher=Aids2031 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and to the second edition hosted in Oslo by [[Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway]].<ref>http://www.aids2031.org/pdfs/2009%20young%20leaders%20summit%20meeting%20report.pdf</ref> Chau chaired the closing session of the 2009 International Congress on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific in Bali, and hosted the opening televised town hall event of the 2010 International AIDS Conference in Vienna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unaids.org/en/KnowledgeCentre/Resources/FeatureStories/archive/2010/20100715_TownHall.asp |title=Join UNAIDS and IAS at Town Hall on reshaping the future of AIDS |publisher=Unaids.org |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> with singer and activist [[Annie Lennox]], UNAIDS Executive Director [[Michel Sidib√©]], U.S. Congresswoman [[Barbara Lee]], and South African Deputy President [[Kgalema Motlanthe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://epaper.bjnews.com.cn/html/2010-08/03/content_132698.htm?div=-1 |title=‰∏ñÁïåËâæÊªãÁóÖÂ§ß‰ºöÊñ∞ËøõÂ±ï -ÂÅ•Â∫∑ÂÖ¨Á§æ¬∑ÂÖ≥Ê≥®-Êñ∞‰∫¨Êä•ÁîµÂ≠êÊä• |publisher=Epaper.bjnews.com.cn |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.kff.org/AIDS2010/July-18/Towards-a-Paradigm-Shift-in-HIV-Treatment.aspx |title=Towards a Paradigm Shift in HIV Treatment and Prevention ‚Äì Kaiser Global Health |publisher=Globalhealth.kff.org |date=18 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> At the same conference, he moderated the innovative financing debate between [[The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria|Global Fund]] chief [[Michel Kazatchkine]] and former French Foreign Minister [[Philippe Douste-Blazy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalhealth.kff.org/AIDS2010/July-21/Funding-Global-Health.aspx |title=Funding Global Health: Can Innovative Mechanisms Save the Day? |publisher=Kaiser Global Health |date=21 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
Chau is a member of aids2031<ref>http://www.aids2031.org/pdfs/asian_economies_in_rapid_transition_hiv_now_and_through_2031%5B2%5D.pdf</ref> and [[Fashion Against AIDS|Designers Against AIDS]].
== Interviews == He sat down with Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe during the 2010 UN General Assembly,<ref name="english.cntv.cn"/> and at the same event with United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon,<ref name="James Chau CCTV UN Millennium summit"/> Indian Foreign Secretary [[Nirupama Rao]],<ref name="James Chau CCTV UN Millennium summit"/> Polish Foreign Minister [[Rados≈Çaw Sikorski]],<ref name="James Chau CCTV UN Millennium summit"/> and South African Health Minister [[Aaron Motsoaledi]]. His other interview guests are Malaysian Prime Minister [[Najib Tun Razak]], Indonesian Trade Minister [[Mari Pangestu]], former [[King Constantine II of Greece]], [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|Prince Edward]], former Botswanan President [[Festus Mogae]],<ref>http://www.unaids.org.cn/uploadFiles/2010081913251993.doc</ref> UNAIDS Executive Director [[Michel Sidib√©]],<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-vq0YxTj6ts |title=James Chau Interviews... UN Under Secretary-General Michel Sidib√© |publisher=YouTube |date=30 September 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eVURMqeCvEc |title=James Chau Live... 2010 International AIDS Conference |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> U.S. Assistant Secretary for Health [[Howard Koh]],<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cSAokwXeAXo |title=James Chau Interviews... U.S. Assistant Secretary for Health Howard Koh |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and First Lady of Georgia [[Sandra Roelofs|Sandra Saakashvili]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bm51g5TIECc |title=James Chau Interviews... First Lady of Georgia Sandra Saakashvili |publisher=YouTube |date=18 July 2010 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> From the arts, he profiled Freedom Towers architect [[Daniel Libeskind]], and in fashion, [[Jimmy Choo]], [[Vivienne Tam]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.james-chau.com/podcast/ |title=Podcast |publisher=James Chau |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and Jason Wu. His interview with Chinese military singer [[Peng Liyuan]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gJKSOsMqKvc |title=James Chau Interviews... Chinese military general Peng Liyuan |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> was a rare television exclusive, and he has also spoken on camera to [[Crown Prince Haakon]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rir705KKi3s |title=HRH Haakon and James Chau on Dignity and Respect ‚Äì HIV/AIDS (Part 1) |publisher=YouTube |date=24 June 2009 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and [[Crown Princess Mette-Marit]]<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0g3gAJ3geRU |title=HRH Mette-Marit and James Chau (Part 3) |publisher=YouTube |date=25 June 2009 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> of Norway, and French virologist [[Fran√ßoise Barr√©-Sinoussi]],<ref name="youtube.com"/> whose co-discovery of HIV won her the Nobel Prize in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2008/press.html |title=The 2008 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine ‚Äì Press Release |publisher=Nobelprize.org |date=6 October 2008 |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>
== Other == He is a [[Freeman of the City of London]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tieba.baidu.com/f?kz=87336474 |title=Guild of Scholars of the City of London_Âë®Âª∫ÊàêÂêß_Ë¥¥Âêß |publisher=Tieba.baidu.com |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> a [[National Press Foundation]] Fellow.,<ref>{{cite web|last=Meyers |first=Bob |url=http://nationalpress.org/blogs/aids/category/j2j/ |title=J2J | NPF Helpdesk | National Press Foundation |publisher=Nationalpress.org |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref> and a representative of the [[British Council]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcouncil.org/goingglobal-gg4-speakers-a-z.htm |title=A to Z ‚Äì Session speakers- Going Global 4 |publisher=British Council |accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref>

Bellotti]] | succeeded2=[[Scott Harshbarger]] | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |birth_name=James Michael Shannon | birth_date={{birth date and age|1952|04|04}} | birth_place= | death_date= | spouse= | religion= | occupation= | residence= | alma_mater= [[Johns Hopkins University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[The George Washington University Law School]] ([[Juris doctor|J.D.]]) }} '''James Michael Shannon''' (born April 4, 1952), is a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[politician]] from [[Massachusetts]]. He served in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] from 1979 to 1985, and later as the [[Massachusetts Attorney General]]. ==Biography== Shannon was born in [[Methuen, Massachusetts]] on April 4, 1952 and grew up in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts|Lawrence]].Anna L. Brownson, Charles Bruce Brownson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=fLtWAAAAYAAJ&q=%22james+m+shannon%22+born+methuen&dq=%22james+m+shannon%22+born+methuen&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IRndU_aREoaxyASw8YCYDQ&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAg Congressional Staff Directory], 1982, page 56 He graduated from [[Phillips Academy]] in 1969 and received his undergraduate degree from [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1973.Phillips Academy Andover, [http://www.andover.edu/About/Newsroom/Documents/DrenchProgram_v1.pdf Program, Dedication of Peter Drench Park at Isham Field], May 24, 2014, page 4Johns Hopkins Magazine online, [http://hub.jhu.edu/magazine/2013/fall/class-notes# Class Notes], Fall 2013, retrieved August 2, 2014 He earned a law degree at [[The George Washington University Law School]] in 1975 and practiced law in Lawrence.American Bankers Association, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=BRzdU8OiINanyATPn4C4Dg&id=W-JLAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22james+m+shannon%22+%22george+washington%22+%22law+school%22+1975&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22james+m+shannon%22 ABA Banking Journal], Volume 74, 1982, page 70Congressional Staff Directory, [https://books.google.com/books?ei=aRzdU_iVNJSvyAStkYGoCw&id=ardWAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22james+m+shannon%22+attorney+lawrence+1976&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22james+m+shannon%22 Advance Locator for Capitol Hill], 1983, page 61 In 1970 and 1971 Shannon was an intern in the office of Congressman [[F. Bradford Morse]].Lowell Sun, [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/45832485/ Young Lawrence Attorney Seeks to Unseat Sen. Wall], March 9, 1976 From 1973 to 1975 he served on the staff of Congressman [[Michael J. Harrington]].Stuart E. Weisberg, [https://books.google.com/books?id=BtTgE0JtL7wC&pg=PA171&lpg=PA171&dq=jim+shannon%22+staff+michael+harrington+congress&source=bl&ots=_wrZK3fweH&sig=D111RC6CJ72rQLXfu0YVlFtd8wA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XfzYU7b7A4nisASVuoK4DA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=jim%20shannon%22%20staff%20michael%20harrington%20congress&f=false Barney Frank: The Story of America's Only Left-handed, Gay, Jewish Congressman], 2009, page 171 In 1976 he ran for the [[Massachusetts State Senate]], losing the Democratic primary to incumbent William X. Wall by only eight votes.Lowell Sun, [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/46539292/ Files for Recount], September 22, 1976Lowell Sun, [https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/46126603/ Legendary Sen. Wall Wins Razor-Thin Victory], September 15, 1976 He was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] in [[U.S. House election, 1978|1978]], succeeding [[Paul E. Tsongas]], who ran successfully for the [[United States Senate]]. Shannon was reelected in [[U.S. House election, 1980|1980]] and [[U.S. House election, 1982|1982]]. In 1981, he was selected to be one of the first ''Young Leaders'' of the [[French-American Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.frenchamerican.org/young-leaders|title=Young Leaders|publisher=[[French-American Foundation]]|accessdate=2015-10-28}} When Senator Tsongas announced his retirement in 1984, Shannon entered the race to succeed him. He was defeated in the Democratic primary by [[Lieutenant Governor of Massachusetts|Lieutenant Governor]] [[John F. Kerry]], who went on to win the seat. Shannon served out the rest of his term in the House, leaving office in January 1985, at which point he was elected to the [[Common Cause]] National Governing Board. In [[Massachusetts general election, 1986#Attorney General|1986]], he was elected [[Attorney General of Massachusetts]], defeating [[Edward F. Harrington]] and serving from 1987 to 1991.Elsa C. Arnett, Harvard Crimson, [http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1986/11/3/attorney-general-pthe-low-key-race-for/ Attorney General], November 3, 1986United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, [http://www.mad.uscourts.gov/bbc/pdf/HARRINGTONEdward.pdf Biography, Edward F. Harrington] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808052549/http://www.mad.uscourts.gov/bbc/pdf/HARRINGTONEdward.pdf |date=2014-08-08 }}, retrieved August 2, 2014 He was defeated for re-election in [[Massachusetts general election, 1990|1990]] by [[Scott Harshbarger]] in the Democratic primary.Andrea Lamberti, MIT Tech, [http://tech.mit.edu/V110/N36/elect.36n.html Silber, Weld Win], September 21, 1990 In 2000 Shannon led [[Bill Bradley]]'s presidential campaign in Massachusetts and was a Bradley delegate to [[2000 Democratic National Convention|Democratic National Convention]].Seth Gitell, [http://www.worcesterphoenix.com/archive/features/99/12/17/GORE.html Going for Broke: Al Gore is Running Out of Money. Be Afraid. Be Very Afraid.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150922045817/http://www.worcesterphoenix.com/archive/features/99/12/17/GORE.html |date=2015-09-22 }}, December 17‚Äì24, 1999Elizabeth Mehren, Los Angeles Times, [http://articles.latimes.com/2000/mar/03/news/mn-5031 New England's Appeal Not Equal to the Sum of Its Delegates], March 3, 2000 He was elected president and Chief Executive Officer of the NFPA ([[National Fire Protection Association]]) in 2002, and served until 2014.National Fire Protection Association, [http://www.nfpa.org/press-room/news-releases/2014/the-pro-board-honors-nfpa-president-james-shannon-with-donation-to-the-research-foundation The Pro Board Honors NFPA President James M. Shannon With Donation to the Fire Protection Research Foundation], June 19, 2014 He became President of the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] on 1 January 2017 for a three-year term.{{Citation | place = CH | url = http://www.iec.ch/about/profile/officers.htm | title = IEC Officers | publisher = International Electrotechnical Commission | year = 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{CongBio|S000286}} * {{C-SPAN|jamesshannon}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=Massachusetts | district=5 | before=[[Paul E. Tsongas]] | after=[[Chester G. Atkins]] | years=1979-1985}} {{s-legal}} {{succession box | title=[[Attorney General of Massachusetts]] | before=[[Francis X. Bellotti]] | after=[[Scott Harshbarger]] | years=1987 – 1991}} {{s-end}} {{USRepMA}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shannon, James}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Massachusetts Democrats]] [[Category:Massachusetts lawyers]] [[Category:Politicians from Lawrence, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Massachusetts Attorneys General]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Massachusetts]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:Phillips Academy alumni]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University alumni]] [[Category:George Washington University Law School alumni]] [[Category:Democratic Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Young Leaders of the French-American Foundation]]

{{about|the English artist and writer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox writer |name = John Berger |image = John Berger-2009 (6).jpg |caption = Berger in 2009 |birth_name = John Peter Berger<ref name="nytimes">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/02/arts/design/john-berger-provocative-art-critic-dies-at-90.html |title=John Berger, Provocative Art Critic, Dies at 90 |work=The New York Times |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> |birth_date = {{birth date|1926|11|5|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Stoke Newington]], [[London]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|2017|1|2|1926|11|5|df=y}} |death_place = [[Antony, Hauts-de-Seine]], France |occupation = Novelist, critic, painter, poet |language = English |nationality = British |education = [[St Edward's School, Oxford]] |alma_mater = [[Chelsea School of Art]]; [[Central School of Art]] |genre = Writer |spouse = |children = 3 |awards = [[James Tait Black Memorial Prize]]; [[Booker Prize]] (1972) }} '''John Peter Berger''' ({{IPAc-en|Àà|b|…úr|…°|…ôr}}; 5 November 1926 ‚Äì 2 January 2017) was an English [[art critic]], novelist, painter and poet. His novel ''[[G. (novel)|G.]]'' won the 1972 [[Booker Prize]], and his essay on art criticism, ''[[Ways of Seeing]]'', written as an accompaniment to a [[BBC]] series, is often used as a university text. He lived in France for more than half a century.
==Early life== Berger was born on 5 November 1926<ref name="nytimes"/> in [[Stoke Newington]], [[London]],<ref name="John Berger obituary">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/jan/02/john-berger-obituary |title=John Berger obituary |work=The Guardian |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref><ref name="newstatesman">{{Cite news |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2015/06/i-think-dead-are-us-john-berger-88 |title=I think the dead are with us": John Berger at 88 |work=The New Statesman |publication-date=11 June 2015 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> the first of two children of Miriam and Stanley Berger.<ref name="theguardian">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/1999/feb/13/books.guardianreview8 |title=Contented exile |work=The Guardian |publication-date=13 February 1999 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref>
His grandfather was from [[Trieste]],<ref name=NSJan10>The Books Interview: John Berger: [http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2010/01/palestine-rema-israel-england The Books Interview: John Berger], accessdate: 2 January 2017</ref> and his father, Stanley, raised as a non-observant [[Jew]] who converted to [[Catholicism]],<ref>[[Andy Merrifield]], ''John Berger'', Reaktion Books (2013), p. 29</ref> had been an infantry officer on the Western Front during the [[World War I|First World War]] and was awarded the [[Military Cross]]<ref name="newstatesman"/><ref name="theguardian2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/oct/30/john-berger-at-90-interview-storyteller |title=John Berger: ‚ÄòIf I‚Äôm a storyteller it‚Äôs because I listen‚Äô |work=The Guardian |publication-date=30 October 2016 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> and an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]].<ref name="litencyc">{{cite web|author=Duncan O'Connor |url=http://www.litencyc.com/php/speople.php?rec=true&UID=380 |title=Literary Encyclopedia | John Berger |website=Litencyc.com |date= |accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref> Berger was educated at [[St Edward's School, Oxford]].<ref name="A radical returns"/> He served in the [[British Army]] from 1944 to 1946.<ref name="The Atlantic Companion to Literature in English">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A_YatfLrgnMC&q=John+berger#v=snippet&q=John%20berger&f=false |title=The Atlantic Companion to Literature in English |last=Ray |first=Ed. Mohit K. |publisher=Atlantic Publishers |year=2007 |isbn=9788126908325 |page=48}}</ref> He enrolled in the [[Chelsea School of Art]]<ref name="A radical returns"/> and the [[Central School of Art]] in London.<ref name="The Atlantic Companion to Literature in English"/>
==Career== Berger began his career as a painter<ref name="bbc">{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-38492516 |title=John Berger, art critic and author of Ways of Seeing, dies |publisher=BBC |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> and exhibited works at a number of London galleries in the late 1940s.<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="litencyc" /> His art has been shown at the Wildenstein, Redfern and [[Leicester Galleries]] in London.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/>
Berger taught drawing at [[St Mary's University, Twickenham|St Mary's teacher training college]].<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> He later became an art critic, publishing many essays and reviews in the ''[[New Statesman]]''.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/><ref name="washingtonpost"/> His [[Marxist humanism]]<ref name="dictionaryofarthistorians">{{cite web|title=Berger, John [Peter]|url=http://arthistorians.info/bergerj|website=arthistorians.info}}</ref> and his strongly stated opinions on [[modern art]] combined to make him a controversial figure early in his career.<ref name="lareviewofbooks">{{Cite news |url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/a-smuggling-operation-john-bergers-theory-of-art/ |title=A Smuggling Operation: John Berger‚Äôs Theory of Art |work=LARB |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=5 January 2017}}</ref> As a statement of political commitment, he titled an early collection of essays ''Permanent Red''.<ref name="newrepublic">{{Cite news |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/126679/many-faces-john-berger |title=The Many Faces of John Berger |work=New Republic |publication-date=30 December 2015 |access-date=5 January 2017}}</ref>
Berger was never a formal member of the [[Communist Party of Great Britain]] (CPGB): rather he was a close associate of it and its front, the [[Artists' International Association|Artists‚Äô International Association]] (AIA), until the latter disappeared in 1953. He was active in the Geneva Club, a discussion group that appears to have overlapped with British communist circles in the 1950s.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://weeklyworker.co.uk/worker/1140/berger-and-stalinism/|title=Berger and Stalinism|last=Parker|first=Lawrence|date=2 February 2017|website=Weekly Worker|access-date=19 January 2018}}</ref>
==Publishing== In 1958, Berger published his first novel, ''A Painter of Our Time'',<ref name="John Berger, art critic and author, dies aged 90">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/jan/02/john-berger-art-critic-and-author-dies-aged-90 |title=John Berger, art critic and author, dies aged 90 |work=The Guardian |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=3 January 2017}}</ref> which tells the story of the disappearance of Janos Lavin, a fictional exiled Hungarian painter, and his diary's discovery by an art critic friend called John.<ref name="theweek">{{Cite news |url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/80124/john-berger-five-key-works-by-the-late-art-critic |title=John Berger: Five key works by the late art critic |work=The Week |publication-date=3 January 2017 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> The work was withdrawn by the publisher under pressure from the [[Congress for Cultural Freedom]] a month after its publication.<ref name="litencyc"/> His next novels were ''The Foot of Clive'' and ''Corker's Freedom'';<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> both of which presented an urban English life of alienation and melancholy. Berger moved to Quincy in the [[Haute-Savoie]], France in 1962 due to his distaste for life in Britain.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/>
In 1972, the [[BBC]] broadcast his television series ''[[Ways of Seeing]]''<ref name="John Berger obituary"/><ref name="bbc"/><ref name="theweek"/> and published its companion text, an introduction to the study of images. The work was derived in part from [[Walter Benjamin]]'s essay "[[The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction]]".<ref name="Digital Humanities Pedagogy: Practices, Principles and Politics">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GmImK8hCPjcC&q=ways+of+seeing+based+on+The+Work+of+Art+in+the+Age+of+Mechanical+Reproduction#v=snippet&q=ways%20of%20seeing%20based%20on%20The%20Work%20of%20Art%20in%20the%20Age%20of%20Mechanical%20Reproduction&f=false |title=Digital Humanities Pedagogy: Practices, Principles and Politics |publisher=Open Book Publishers |year=2012 |isbn=9781909254251 |page=301}}</ref> [[File:John Berger-2009 (4).jpg|thumb|John Berger]] Berger's novel ''[[G. (novel)|G.]]'', a [[picaresque]] romance set in Europe in 1898, won the [[James Tait Black Memorial Prize]] and the [[Booker Prize]] in 1972.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> Berger donated half the Booker cash prize to the [[Black Panther Party]] in Britain, and retained half to support his work on the study on migrant workers that became ''[[A Seventh Man]]'', asserting that both endeavors represented aspects of his political struggle.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=McNay |title=Berger turns tables on Booker |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/1972/nov/24/mainsection.fromthearchive |work=The Guardian |date=24 November 1972 |accessdate=5 December 2009 |location=London}}</ref>
Berger's sociological writings include ''A Fortunate Man: The Story of a Country Doctor'' (1967)<ref name="John Berger's A Fortunate Man: a masterpiece of witness">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/feb/07/john-sassall-country-doctor-a-fortunate-man-john-berger-jean-mohr |title=John Berger's A Fortunate Man: a masterpiece of witness |work= The Guardian |publication-date=7 February 2015 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> and ''A Seventh Man: Migrant Workers in Europe'' (1975).<ref name="A Seventh Man">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/dec/18/seventh-man-john-berger-review |title=A Seventh Man: Migrant Workers in Europe by John Berger and Jean Mohr ‚Äì review |work= The Guardian |publication-date=18 December 2010 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> Berger and photographer [[Jean Mohr]], his frequent collaborator, sought to document and understand the experiences of peasants.<ref name="A Seventh Man: A Book of Images and Words about the Experience of Migrant Workers in Europe">{{Cite book |title=A Seventh Man: A Book of Images and Words about the Experience of Migrant Workers in Europe |last=Berger |first=John |last2=Mohr |first2=Jean |last3=Blomberg |first3=Sven |publisher=Verso |year=2010 |isbn=9781844676491}}</ref> Their subsequent book, ''Another Way of Telling'', discusses and illustrates their documentary technique and treats the theory of photography through Berger's essays and Mohr's photographs.<ref name="Another Way of Telling">{{cite web|title=ANOTHER WAY OF TELLING|url=http://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/12330/another-way-of-telling-by-john-berger/9780679737247/|website=Penguin Random House}}</ref> His studies of individual artists include ''The Success and Failure of [[Picasso]]'' (1965), a survey of that modernist's career, and ''Art and Revolution: [[Ernst Neizvestny]], Endurance, and the Role of the Artist in the USSR'' (1969).<ref name="John Berger obituary"/>
In the 1970s, Berger collaborated on three films with the Swiss director [[Alain Tanner]]:<ref name="nytimes"/><ref name="The Atlantic Companion to Literature in English"/> He wrote or co-wrote ''La Salamandre'' (1971), ''The Middle of the World'' (1974), and ''[[Jonah who will be 25 in the year 2000]]'' (1976).<ref>Christian Dimitriu, ''Alain Tanner'', Paris: Henri Veyrier, 1985, pp. 125‚Äì134.</ref> His major fictional work of the 1980s, the trilogy ''Into Their Labours'' (consisting of the novels ''[[Pig Earth]]'', ''Once in Europa'', and ''Lilac and Flag''),<ref name="theguardian"/><ref name="On John Berger: Telling Stories">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RbC8CgAAQBAJ&q=trilogy+into+their+labours#v=snippet&q=trilogy%20into%20their%20labours&f=false |title=On John Berger: Telling Stories |publisher=BRILL |year=2015 |isbn=9789004308114 |page=24}}</ref> treats the European peasant experience from its farming roots to contemporary economic and political displacement and urban poverty.<ref name="theguardian"/><ref name="nytimes2"/> In 1974, Berger co-founded the [[For Beginners, LLC|Writers and Readers Publishing Cooperative Ltd]] in London with [[Arnold Wesker]], [[Lisa Appignanesi]], [[Richard Appignanesi]], [[Chris Searle]], [[Glenn Thompson (publisher)|Glenn Thompson,]] [[Sian Williams|Si√¢n Williams]], and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paraprincipiantes.com/html/quienes.shtml |title=Libros para Principiantes: Quienes somos |website=Paraprincipiantes.com |date= |accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref> The cooperative was active until the early 1980s.<ref name="aalbc">{{Cite news |url=http://aalbc.com/reviews/remembering_glenn_thompson.htm |title=Remembering Glenn Thompson |work=African American Literature Book Club |access-date=5 January 2017}}</ref>
In later essays, Berger wrote about photography, art, politics, and memory. He published in ''The Shape of a Pocket'' a correspondence with [[Subcomandante Marcos]],<ref name="publico">{{Cite news |url=https://www.publico.pt/2017/01/02/culturaipsilon/noticia/morreu-john-berger-um-artista-total-1756862 |title=Morreu John Berger, um artista (e um espectador) total |work=Publico |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref> and penned short stories that appeared in ''[[The Threepenny Review]]'' and ''[[The New Yorker]]''. His sole volume of poetry is ''Pages of the Wound'', though other volumes, such as the theoretical essay ''And Our Faces, My Heart, Brief as Photos'' contain poetry. His later novels include ''To the Wedding'', a love story dealing with the [[AIDS]] crisis,<ref name="theguardian2" /><ref name="Making Sense: Sense Perception in the British Novel of the 1980s and 1990s">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nCIlg2dR5q0C&q=To+the+wedding#v=snippet&q=To%20the%20wedding&f=false |title=Making Sense: Sense Perception in the British Novel of the 1980s and 1990s |last=Hertel |first=Ralf |publisher=Rodopi |year=2005 |isbn=9789042018648 |page=74}}</ref> and ''[[King: A Street Story]]'', a novel about homelessness and shantytown life told from the perspective of a stray dog.<ref name="theguardian"/><ref name="Making Sense: Sense Perception in the British Novel of the 1980s and 1990s"/> Initially, Berger insisted that his name be kept off the cover and title page of ''King'', wanting the novel to be received on its own merits.<ref name="the telegraph">{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/4724662/Portrait-of-the-artist-as-a-wild-old-man.html |title=Portrait of the artist as a wild old man |work=The Telegraph |publication-date=23 July 2001 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref>
Berger's 1980 volume ''About Looking'' includes an influential chapter, "Why Look at Animals?"<ref name="Critical Animal Studies: An Introduction">{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1TmbF3ZgvuoC&q=why+look+at+animals%3F#v=snippet&q=why%20look%20at%20animals%3F&f=false |title=Critical Animal Studies: An Introduction |last=McCance |first=Dawne |publisher=SUNY Press |year=2013 |isbn=9781438445342 |page=45}}</ref> It is cited by numerous scholars in the interdisciplinary field of [[animal studies]]. The chapter was later reproduced in a [[Penguin Great Ideas]] selection of essays of the same title.<ref name="Critical Animal Studies: An Introduction"/>
Berger's novel ''From A to X'' was long-listed for the 2008 Booker Prize;<ref name="nytimes"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global/2008/jul/29/bookerprize|title=Booker longlist boost for first-time novelists|author=Michelle Pauli|work=the Guardian|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref> ''Bento's Sketchbook'' (2011) has been described as "a characteristically ''[[sui generis]]'' work combining an engagement with the thought of the 17th-century lens grinder, draughtsman, and philosopher [[Baruch Spinoza]], with a study of drawing and a series of semi-autobiographical sketches".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/apr/23/john-berger-life-in-writing | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Nicholas | last=Wroe | title=John Berger: a life in writing | date=23 April 2011}}</ref> Among his last works is ''Confabulations'' (essays, 2016).<ref name="theguardian2"/><ref name="independent uk">{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/john-berger-dead-booker-prize-winning-author-art-critic-dies-aged-90-a7506346.html |title=John Berger dead: Booker Prize-winning author and art critic dies aged 90 |work=Independent |publication-date=2 January 2017 |access-date=4 January 2017}}</ref>
==Other work== In 1999, Berger voiced both twin brother characters Archie and Albert Crisp in the video game ''[[Grand Theft Auto: London 1969]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rockstargames.com/newswire/article/60097/RIP-John-Berger-Famous-British-Novelist-Art-Critic-and-Secret-GTA-Lond|title=RIP John Berger, Famous British Novelist, Art Critic and Secret GTA: London Villain|publisher=[[Rockstar Games]]|date=2017-01-03|accessdate=2017-01-04}}</ref>
He was a member of the Support Committee of the [[Russell Tribunal#2009‚Äì2014: On Palestine (Barcelona, London, Cape Town, New York, Brussels)|Russell Tribunal on Palestine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.russelltribunalonpalestine.com/en/about-rtop/patrons|title=Patrons {{!}} Russell Tribunal on Palestine|website=www.russelltribunalonpalestine.com|access-date=2017-01-08}}</ref>
==Personal life== Berger married three times,<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> first to artist and illustrator Patt Marriott in 1949; the marriage was childless and the couple divorced.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> In the mid-1950s, he married the Russian Anya Bostock (n√©e Anna Sisserman), with whom he had two children, Katya Berger and [[Jacob Berger]]; the couple divorced in the mid-1970s.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> Soon afterwards, he married Beverly Bancroft, with whom he had one child, Yves.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/> Beverly died in 2013.<ref name="John Berger obituary"/>
Berger died at his home in [[Antony, Hauts-de-Seine|Antony]], France on 2 January 2017 at the age of 90.<ref name="nytimes"/><ref>{{cite news|title=John Berger, art critic and author, dies aged 90|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/jan/02/john-berger-art-critic-and-author-dies-aged-90|work=The Guardian|date=2 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url = http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_OBIT_JOHN_BERGER?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2017-01-02-15-21-08|title = John Berger, pioneering art critic and author, dies at 90|work = Associated Press|date = 2 January 2017|accessdate = 2 January 2017|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170103140225/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_OBIT_JOHN_BERGER?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2017-01-02-15-21-08|archivedate = 3 January 2017|df = dmy-all}}</ref>

The book, published by OBJECTIF, features new texts by and about John Berger plus a catalogue section of images, information and stories from the invited artists in the main exhibition held on 8 July ‚Äì 26 August 2017 at Mandell‚Äôs Gallery, Norwich. It contains two previously unpublished sequences of correspondence on art and communications between John Berger and his daughter Katya Berger Andreadakis along with tributes and stories from: Anne Michaels, Yves Berger, Eul√†lia Bosch, Geoff Dyer, Gareth Evans, Paul Gordon and Tom Overton. The book also features a compilation of writings on the art and practice of drawing collected together by John Christie, from across John Berger‚Äôs art criticism, fiction, essays and letters.

[[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|House of Representatives]] | term = | term_start = 1851 | term_end = 1852 | monarch = | office1 = Member of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]
[[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|House of Nobles]] | term1 = | term_start1 = 1853 | term_end1 = 1855 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{circa|1824}} | birth_place = [[Honolulu, Hawaii]]? | death_date = May 7, 1856 (aged 32) | death_place = [[Honolulu, Hawaii]] | resting_place = [[Kawaiaha ªo Church]] | spouse = Puakele?{{Hawaiian Dictionaries | Marriages: Oahu (1832-1910) | record |dic=gene |id=D10-000020 |q= Kekaulahao |accessdate= June 18, 2014 }} | children = | parents = A. Kaina | relatives = [[John Kalili]] (cousin) | nationality = [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Hawaiian]] | other_names = | alma_mater = [[Lahainaluna Seminary]] | known_for = | occupation = Lawyer, Judge, Politician | religion = [[Congregational church|Congregationalism]] | signature = Kekaulahao 1842 signature.jpg }} '''Joshua Kekaulahao''' ({{circa|1824}} ‚Äì May 7, 1856) was a politician and judge in the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. His name is often spelled ''Kekaulahau''. ==Biography== Born around 1824, Kekaulahao was the son of A. Kaina, who was a captain of the interisland steamer ''Akamai''.{{cite news |title= They Are Passing Away |date= December 16, 1858 |newspaper= The Pacific Commercial Advertiser |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1858-12-16/ed-1/seq-2/}}{{cite news |title= Died |date= May 10, 1856 |newspaper= The Polynesian |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1856-05-10/ed-1/seq-2/ }} A sister of his married [[Jonah Kapena]]. Kekaulahao also had a son who died in the [[smallpox]] epidemic of 1853. A vaccination administered by a Honolulu physician failed to save the child, and he died at [[Lahaina]] after bathing in the sea to alleviate the malignant case of smallpox.{{sfn|Greer|1965|page=237}}{{cite news |title= A Lover of Justice |date= September 3, 1853 |newspaper= The Polynesian |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1853-09-03/ed-1/seq-2/}} The 1853 epidemic resulted in about and 2,485 reported deaths but the death toll was probably as high as five or six thousand, about eight percent of the islands' population.{{sfn|Van Dyke|2008|page=21}}{{sfn|Kuykendall|1965|pages=411‚Äì413}}{{sfn|Kohn|2008|pages=158‚Äì159}} The Hawaiian government made smallpox vaccination compulsory in 1854.{{sfn|Greer|1965|pages=237‚Äì238}} Kekaulahao was one of the first generation of [[Native Hawaiians|Hawaiians]] to receive a western education by the [[List of Missionaries to Hawaii|American missionaries]] who arrived in Hawaii in 1820. In 1836, he began his education at [[Lahainaluna Seminary]] and graduated in 1841. Some of his classmates included writer [[S. N. Haleole]], historian [[Samuel Kamakau]] and future royal governor [[George Luther Kapeau]].{{cite news |title= Papa Inoa O Ke Kula Nui O Lahainaluna |date= May 19, 1858 |newspaper= Ka Hae Hawaii |url= http://nupepa-hawaii.com/2014/05/30/lahainaluna-school-student-roster-where-it-all-started-1858/ }} After graduating from Lahainaluna, Kekaulahao became a practicing attorney in the early days of the kingdom. He entered the service of the Hawaiian government as a [[Clerk (legislature)|clerk]] for the House of Nobles in the 1846 session of the [[Legislature of the Hawaiian Kingdom|Hawaiian legislature]].{{sfn|Osorio|2002|pages=72, 76, 93}}{{sfn|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918|page=23}} Throughout much of the early 1850s, he led an active career in the politics of the kingdom. In 1851, he was elected as a member of the House of Representatives, the lower house of the legislature, representing the district of  ªEwa, O ªahu.{{sfn|Osorio|2002|page=69}} Kekaulahao would serve as a representative from 1851 to 1852. On April 14, 1853, he was elevated to the position of a member of the House of Nobles, the upper house of the legislature traditionally reserved for the chiefs, serving until 1855.{{sfn|Osorio|2002|page=109}} Initially serving as a secretary on the Board of Land Commissioners, he succeeded [[Zorobabela Ka ªauwai]] as one of the commissioners on the board after Ka ªauwai's resignation. The board was in charge of settling or quieting land claims of the [[Great MƒÅhele]]. He served on the board from 1850 to 1855.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1965|page=280}}{{sfn|Hawaii. Dept. of the Interior|1853|page=30}}{{sfn|Van Dyke|2008|page=35}} In April 24, 1855, Kekaulahao was appointed Circuit Judge for O ªahu succeeding his cousin [[John Kalili]], who died in office.{{cite web |url=http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/import/import/Government%20Office%20Holders%20-%20Name%20IMJ/K/Kekaulahao,%20Joshua.jpg |title= Kekaulahao, Joshua office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate= June 17, 2014 }} Kekaulahao died on May 7, 1856 in [[Honolulu]] at the age of thirty-two. Two years later in 1858, he and five members of his family including his younger brother, father, son, sister, and cousin John Kalili were buried in the cemetery of the [[Kawaiaha ªo Church]] in a ceremony which included the use of [[Niihau]] mats as burial goods. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|author=Hawaii|editor-last=Lydecker|editor-first=Robert Colfax|volume=|title=Roster Legislatures of Hawaii, 1841-1918|location=Honolulu|publisher=Hawaiian Gazette Company|year=1918|page=|url=https://archive.org/details/rosterlegislatur00hawarich|ref={{harvid|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918}}}} * {{cite book|author=Hawaii. Dept. of the Interior|title=Report of the Minister of the Interior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AgJQAAAAYAAJ|year=1853|publisher=Polynesian Press|location=Honolulu|ref=harv}} * {{cite journal|last=Greer|first=Richard A.|title=Oahu's Ordeal ‚Äì The Smallpox Epidemic of 1853, Part 1|work=Hawaii Historical Review, Vol. I. No. 12 |hdl= 10524/12083 |year=1965 |location=Honolulu |publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society |pages= 221‚Äì242 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Kohn|first=George C. |title=Encyclopedia of Plague and Pestilence: From Ancient Times to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tzRwRmb09rgC|year=2008|publisher=Infobase Publishing|location=New York City|isbn=978-1-4381-2923-5|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Kuykendall|first=Ralph Simpson|authorlink=Ralph Simpson Kuykendall|title=The Hawaiian Kingdom 1778‚Äì1854, Foundation and Transformation|url=http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=kingdom1&l=en|volume=1|year=1965|origyear=1938|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=0-87022-431-X|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Osorio|first=Jon Kamakawiwo ªole|title=Dismembering LƒÅhui: A History of the Hawaiian Nation to 1887|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q5k6W_6QOFgC|year=2002|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-8248-2549-2|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last=Van Dyke|first=Jon M.|title=Who Owns the Crown Lands of Hawai ªi?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IjZPcGb2R08C|year=2008|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Honolulu|isbn=978-0-8248-3211-7|ref=harv}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kekaulahao, Joshua}} [[Category:1820s births]] [[Category:1856 deaths]] [[Category:Native Hawaiian people]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Kingdom of Hawaii House of Representatives]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii judges]] [[Category:Lahainaluna School alumni]] [[Category:Burials at Kawaiaha ªo Church]]

'''Linda Mart√≠n Alcoff''' is a professor of philosophy at [[Hunter College]], [[City University of New York]]. Alcoff specializes in [[epistemology]], [[feminism]], [[race theory]] and [[existentialism]]. She is the author of ''Visible Identities: Race, Gender, and the Self'' (2006) and ''The Future of Whiteness'' (2015).
Alcoff has called for greater inclusion of historically underrepresented groups in philosophy and notes that philosophers from these groups have created new fields of inquiry, including [[feminist philosophy]], [[critical race theory]], and LGBTQ philosophy.<ref name=Mann>{{cite journal|last=Mann|first=Bonnie|title=Three White Men Walk into a Bar|journal=Radical Philosophy Review|year=2013|volume=16|issue=3|pages=733‚Äì746|doi=10.5840/radphilrev201316354}}</ref><ref name=CHE>{{cite journal|last=Wilson|first=Robin|title=Women Challenge Male Philosophers to Make Room in Unfriendly Field|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/Female-Philosophers-Shake-Up/136629/|journal=Chronicle of Higher Education|date=2013-01-18|volume=59|issue=19|pages=A1-A6}}</ref> To help address these issues, with Paul Taylor and William Wilkerson, she started "The Pluralist‚Äôs Guide to Philosophy".<ref name=TPM>{{cite journal|last=O'Connor|first=James|title=Pluralist Guide scrutinised|journal=The Philosophers Magazine|date=Jan{{ndash}}Mar 2012|issue=56|page=6|url=http://onlinedigeditions.com/publication/?i=91079&p=8|accessdate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> From 2012 to 2013 she served as president of the [[American Philosophical Association]], Eastern Division.<ref name=APApast>{{cite web|title=APA Divisional Presidents & Addresses|url=http://www.apaonline.org/?page=presidents|publisher=American Philosophical Association|accessdate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> In February 2018 she was appointed president of the board of directors of Hypatia, Inc., the non-profit corporation that owns the feminist philosophy journal [[Hypatia (journal)|''Hypatia'']].<ref name=search23Feb2018>{{cite web|title=Announcement from Hypatia's Board of Directors and Task Force Co-Chairs|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/announcements/announcement-hypatias-board-directors-task-force-co-chairs/|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301164503/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/announcements/announcement-hypatias-board-directors-task-force-co-chairs/|archivedate=1 March 2018|date=23 February 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name=Weinberg24July2017>{{cite news|last1=Weinberg|first1=Justin|title=Hypatia‚Äôs Associate Editors Resign|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/07/24/hypatias-associate-editors-resign/|work=Daily Nous|date=24 July 2017}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Alcoff was born in Panama,<ref name=YancyAlcoff/> the second of two girls to an Irish mother, Laura, and Panamanian father, Miguel Angel Mart√≠n, who met each other while studying at [[Florida State University]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Martin|title=The Future of Whiteness|date=2015|publisher=Polity Press|location=Cambridge and Malden|pages=30‚Äì31, 34}}</ref> Her father became a professor of history at the [[Universidad de Panama]].<ref>Alcoff, Linda Mart√≠n (2006). ''Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self''. Oxford University Press. pp. vii, 8.</ref> When her parents separated, Alcoff moved with her mother and sister to Florida when she was three.<ref name=YancyAlcoff>{{cite news|last1=Yancy|first1=George|last2=Alcoff|first2=Linda Mart√≠n|title=Philosophy‚Äôs Lost Body and Soul|url=https://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/philosophys-lost-body-and-soul/|work=The New York Times|date=4 February 2015}}</ref> In 1980 she earned a BA with honors in philosophy from [[Georgia State University]] and in 1983 an MA, also in philosophy. She did her doctoral work at [[Brown University]], completing her dissertation under the direction of [[Ernest Sosa]], [[Martha Nussbaum]], and [[Richard Schmitt]] and receiving her PhD in 1987.<ref name=CV/>
==Career== ===Positions held=== After spending a year as assistant professor of philosophy at [[Kalamazoo College]], Alcoff moved to [[Syracuse University]], where she taught for the next ten years. She was tenured and promoted to associate professor in 1995 and full professor in 1999. She held visiting positions at [[Cornell University]] (1994‚Äì1995), [[Aarhus University]] (November 1999), [[Florida Atlantic University]] (Fall 2000), and Brown University (Spring 2001). She took a position as professor of philosophy and women's studies at [[SUNY Stony Brook]] in 2002‚Äì2003. In 2009 she became professor of philosophy at [[Hunter College]] and the [[City University of New York Graduate Center]].<ref name=CV>{{cite web|last=Alcoff|first=Linda Mart√≠n|title=Curriculum Vitae|url=http://www.alcoff.com/curriculum-vitae|publisher=www.alcoff.com}}</ref>
From 2010 to 2013 Alcoff was joint editor-in-chief, with [[Ann Cudd]], of the feminist philosophy journal [[Hypatia (journal)|''Hypatia'']].<ref name=editorialboardMarch2018>{{cite web|title=Editorial board|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301224919/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|archivedate=1 March 2018|date=1 March 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref> She served on its board of associate editors during the [[Hypatia transracialism controversy]] in 2017, when the associate editors controversially issued a public apology for the publication of a peer-reviewed article in ''Hypatia'' that compared [[Transracial (identity)|transracialism]] to the decision to change [[Transgender|gender expression]].<ref name=Brubaker18May2017>[[Rogers Brubaker|Brubaker, Roger]] (18 May 2017). [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/18/opinion/the-uproar-over-transracialism.html "The Uproar Over 'Transracialism'"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Martin|title=Here's my take.|url=https://www.facebook.com/lsalcoff/posts/10156108465053047|publisher=Facebook|archiveurl=https://archive.is/PYN7m|archivedate=15 May 2017|date=4 May 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref> The journal's management subsequently established a task force to resolve the journal's governance issues; Alcoff became president of the board of directors of Hypatia, Inc., in February 2018.<ref name=search23Feb2018/><ref name=Weinberg24July2017/>
===Research=== Alcoff has written widely on subjects including Foucault, sexual violence, the politics of epistemology, gender and race identity, and Latino issues.<ref name=CV/> She has authored three books - ''Real Knowing: New Versions of Coherence Theory'' (1996), ''Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self'' (2006), and ''The Future of Whiteness'' (2015).<ref name=CV/> She has also edited ten volumes, written a large number of peer-reviewed articles, and contributed a large number of book and encyclopedia chapters and entries.<ref name=CV/>
''Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self'' attempted to offer a unified account of social identity by bridging her previous work in epistemology, metaphysics, and the politics of ethnicity, race, and gender.<ref name=ndpr1>{{cite journal|last=Sundstrom|first=Ronald|title=Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self (Review)|url=http://ndpr.nd.edu/news/visible-identities-race-gender-and-the-self/|journal=Notre Dame Philosophical Review|date=22 June 2006}}</ref> In it, Alcoff suggested that geographic location has significant implications for social identity above and beyond those conveyed by other contributors to identity (although she does not view such implications as deterministic).<ref name=ndpr1/>
===Awards=== Alcoff has received several honors and awards, including an honorary doctorate from the [[University of Oslo]] in September 2011, and the Caribbean Philosophical Association's Frantz Fanon Prize for 2009 for her book ''Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self''. She was recognized as a Distinguished Woman in Philosophy by the [[Society for Women in Philosophy]] in 2005, and held the Meredith Professorship for Excellence in Teaching at Syracuse University from 1995‚Äì1998.<ref name=CV/>
==Selected works== *{{cite book|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Mart√≠n|title=Real Knowing: New Versions of the Coherence Theory|date=1996|publisher=Cornell University Press|location=New York}} *{{cite book | last = Alcoff | first = Linda | contribution = Cultural feminism versus post-structuralism: the identity crisis in feminist theory | editor-last1 = Nicholson | editor-first1 = Linda | title = The Second Wave: A Reader in Feminist Theory | pages = 330‚Äì355 | publisher = Routledge | location = New York | year = 1997 | isbn = 9780415917612}} *Alcoff, Linda Mart√≠n (2006). ''Visible Identities: Race, Gender and the Self''. Oxford University Press. * {{cite book | last1 = Alcoff | first1 = Linda | last2 = Kittay | first2 = Eva | author-link2 = Eva Kittay | title = The Blackwell Guide to Feminist Philosophy | publisher = Blackwell Publishing | location = Malden, MA, and Oxford | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780631224273 }} *{{cite book|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Mart√≠n|title=The Future of Whiteness|date=2015|publisher=Polity Press|location=Cambridge and Malden, MA}} *{{cite book|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Mart√≠n|title=Rape and Resistance|date=2018| isbn = 9780745691916}}
